{{Infobox VG | title = Battle Circuit | image = [[Image:Battle Circuit flyer.png|Arcade flyer for Battle Circuit]] |developer = [[Capcom|Capcom Co., Ltd.]] |publisher = [[Capcom|Capcom Co., Ltd.]] |designer = Noritaka Funamizo ([[Game producer|producer]])
Yoshiki Okamoto ([[Game producer|producer]])
Syun Nishigaki ([[composer]]) |engine = |release = '''[[Japan|JPN]]''' / '''[[PAL region|PAL]]''' [[March 19]], [[1997]] |genre = [[Beat 'em up]] |modes = [[Multiplayer game|4-player]] |cabinet = Upright |display = [[Raster graphics|Raster]], standard resolution
horizontal orientation |arcade system = [[CPS-2]] |platforms = [[Arcade Game|Arcade]] |media = |input = 8-way [[Joystick]], 2 [[Button (control)|Buttons]] }} {{nihongo|'''''Battle Circuit'''''|BATTLE CIRCUIT|Batoru Saakitto}} is an [[action game|action]] "[[beat 'em up]]" [[video game|game]] developed and published by [[Capcom]] for the [[CPS-2]] [[arcade machine|arcade]] [[hardware]] for [[Japan]] and [[Europe]] in 1997. Taking place in an alternate future earth, the game revolves around a group of [[bounty hunters]] who must capture the [[mad scientist]] Dr. Saturn and secure a sophisticated computer disc carrying a program known as the "[[Shiva]] System". The game contains [[comic book|comic]]-like characters in a futuristic [[science fiction]] setting. ==Development== ''Battle Circuit'' was developed by producers Noritaka Funamizo and Yoshiki Okamoto of Capcom's arcade production team in early 1997. In-game credits for ''Battle Circuit'', English-language version. 1997 While structurally very similar to the company's early scrolling action games like ''[[Final Fight]]'' and ''[[Alien vs. Predator (arcade game)|Alien vs. Predator]]'', ''Battle Circuit'' is set apart stylistically by employing a [[manga]]-style [[science fiction|sci-fi]] approach to story and character artwork. The art staff, overseen by Ohnishi Hiroki and Yamamoto Kouji, In-game credits for ''Battle Circuit'', English-language version. 1997 created an assortment of characters with features reminiscent of older Capcom characters and superfluous [[comic book]] elements. The game saw a speedy translation effort that effectively made the title available in both Japan and parts of Europe on the same day. Though there are no game play differences between the [[Japanese language|Japanese]] and [[English language]] versions of the game, a few pieces of Japanese dialogue were omitted from the European release. The game was not released in [[North America|North American]] arcades or any other part of the world after its initial release. "[http://www.vgmuseum.com/images/arcade3/03/3.htm Battle Circuit Arcade Info]" ''VGMuseum''. URL Accessed on [[November 19]], [[2006]]. ==Game play== [[Image:battle circuit.jpg|left|thumb|225px|In-game screenshot of ''Battle Circuit'' with four players.]] ''Battle Circuit'''s [[arcade cabinet]] provided support for up to four simultaneous players who can each assume the role of five possible characters. "[http://www.klov.com/game_detail.php?game_id=7038 Battle Circuit]" ''Killer List of Videogames''. URL Accessed on [[November 19]], [[2006]]. Players must progress through a number of levels made up of horizontally scrolling screens filled with enemy characters that must be defeated using a combination of attacks and movement abilities each character utilizes. Every character is given a selection of these abilities that can be expanded as game play progress by purchasing special "upgrade discs" after the completion of each level using coins obtained by defeating enemies. These techniques are often a combination of either of the two action buttons and the [[joystick]], and can add additional varieties to a given character's arsenal. A player must attack enemies until their health (indicated by a bar under the player's when the enemy is attacked) is reduced to 0 and they are thus knocked out. If a player's health bar is depleted, they will also become knocked out and must use up one life to continue. If all of a player's lives are depleted in this fashion, the game will end unless more credits are purchased. Special techniques called "Battle Downloads" can be used by pressing both action buttons while jumping, which results in the player and his allies (if any are present) gaining a certain attribute, the effect of which is unique to each character. Cyber Blue, for example, can use his Battle Download "Power Up" to increase the amount of damage dealt by attacks, while Yellow Iris' "Speed Up" increases attack speed. A character will start with a stock of two of these techniques to use per life, and can obtain more from capsules scattered throughout the levels, up to a maximum of five. Various items can be found inside destructible objects such as barrels and crates, and can provide the player with additional health or add points to their total score. Once a player's score reaches a set amount, they are rewarded with an extra life that will give them another chance to continue from where they were knocked out by an enemy. ==Story== Taking place in the future year [[21st century|20XX]], ''Battle Circuit'' follows the exploits of a group of super-powered bounty hunters as they apprehend wanted criminals (identified by special serial numbers) in the city of Neo Koba. The game begins with player attempting to apprehend criminal 9696X, a scientist named Doctor Saturn and his [[blob]]-like [[sidekick]] aboard his [[spaceship]] orbiting Earth. After the battle, the character selected by the player returns to his employer, Harry, and is promptly given another assignment to capture the leader of the "Delete Gang", Johnny, who holds a valuable [[floppy disc]] in his possession. The bounty hunter then confronts Johnny at his [[disco]] hideout and learns that the disc contains a malicious [[computer program]] known as the "Shiva System", which is capable of control all the computerized systems in the world. As one of the characters chosen, player's must travel through various levels and fight through various members of the Delete Gang to obtain the disc and claim their bounty. In-game script for ''Battle Circuit'', English-language version. 1997 ==Characters== ''Battle Circuit'' contains five possible characters for the player to choose from, each with their own unique attacks and Battle Download ability. Though each of the character's real names are mentioned in their individual character profiles during the opening demo, they are mostly referred to by their codenames, each indicating a physical attribute and corresponding color. * Brian Bruno "'''Cyber Blue'''": A seasoned bounty hunter with several [[cyborg|cybernetic]] attachments to his body, giving him the ability to discharge electricity and project energy from his fists. * Andrey Mishucin "'''Captain Silver'''": A highly-accomplished bounty hunter who can stretch and shape his body at will. His powers give him the ability to project ice particles from his body, as well as create a number of objects from his suit. Because of the vast nature of his powers, they will threaten to overwhelm him if he should ever lose concentration. In-game script for ''Battle Circuit'', English-language version. 1997 * Diana Martines "'''Yellow Iris'''" (Called "'''Yellow Beast'''" in the original [[Japanese language|Japanese]] version): A part-time [[fashion model]] whose feral appearance gives her access to a number of clawing and agility-based techniques. She is also skilled with a [[whip]] and is accompanied by her pet [[fox]] "Fin". In-game script for ''Battle Circuit'', English-language version. 1997 * Pinky "'''Pink Ostrich'''": A large, sentient, pink [[ostrich]] with an [[eye patch]] and jewel [[necklace]] who is always accompanied by her owner, a young girl named Pola. Purported, she is the "only ostrich in the world who can fly", In-game script for ''Battle Circuit'', English-language version. 1997 and attacks with an assortment of aerial and spinning techniques. * Unknown "'''Alien Green'''": An [[Extraterrestrial life|alien]] creature of unknown origin who resembles a large [[venus flytrap]] with leg-like roots and a large [[eye]] in its abdomen. Its attacks mostly center around its vine-like arms, which it can quickly swing to create whirlwinds, as well as grab opponents and slam them against the ground. ==Stage Bosses== *Dr. Saturn *Jonny *Black Elephant, and Barbara *B.O.B, and Octopus mk2 *Dave, and Doc & Jennifer *Chris, Betsy,Cathy, Cyber Samurai, and Zipang *Barbara, Asura, Sandra, Octopus mk3, Black Elephant, and Pluto *Master Program ==Music== ''Battle Circuit'''s background music was composed by Syun Nishigaki of Capcom Arcade Sound Team, and has a recurring [[pop music|pop]] and [[electronic music|electronic]] theme present throughout the game. The music was recorded using only synth-based computer generated sound, a common recording medium for arcade games on the [[CPS-2]]. An official soundtrack entitled ''Battle Circuit Original Soundtrack'' (catalog number VICL-60056) was released commercially in Japan by [[Victor Entertainment]] on [[July 2]], 1997 and retailed for [[Japanese yen|¥]]2,205. "[http://www.gmronline.com/info.asp?CatNumber=VICL-60056 Battle Circuit Original Soundtrack]" ''Game Music Revolution''. URL Accessed on [[November 19]], [[2006]]. ==See also== [[List_of_fighting_games#Beat_.27em_ups|List of '''beat 'em ups''']] ==References==
==External links== * [http://www.gamefaqs.com/coinop/arcade/data/574650.html Battle Circuit at GameFAQs] *{{KLOV game|id=7038}} * [http://www.vgmuseum.com/images/arcade3/03/3.htm VG Museum: Battle Circuit] [[Category:1997 video games]] [[Category:Arcade games]] [[Category:Capcom games]] [[Category:Beat 'em ups]] [[Category:Cooperative video games]] [[ja:バトルサーキット]]

{{Infobox Wrestling event

|image=BadBlood04.jpg
|tagline=He's Back. Watch Yours
|theme="Sold Me" by [[Seether]]
|promotion=[[World Wrestling Entertainment]]
|brand=[[WWE Raw|Raw]]
|date=June 13, 2004
|venue=[[Nationwide Arena]]
|city=[[Columbus, Ohio]]
|attendance=9,000<ref name="pwh">{{cite web|url=http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wwf/badd.html#2004|title=Bad Blood 2004|accessdate=2008-08-18|publisher=Pro Wrestling History}}</ref>
|lastevent=[[Judgment Day (2004)]]
|nextevent=[[The Great American Bash (2004)]]
|event=[[WWE Bad Blood|Bad Blood]]
|lastevent2=[[Bad Blood (2003)]]
|nextevent2='''''Final'''''
}}

'''Bad Blood (2004)''' was a [[professional wrestling]] [[pay-per-view]] event produced by [[World Wrestling Entertainment]] (WWE), which took place on June 13, 2004 at the [[Nationwide Arena]] in [[Columbus, Ohio]]. It was the third and final annual [[WWE Bad Blood|Bad Blood]] event. Seven professional wrestling matches, [[mock combat|performances]] with pre-determined outcomes between wrestlers with fictional personalities that are portrayed as real, were featured on the event's [[card (sports)|card]]. The buildup to the matches and the scenarios that took place before, during, and after the event were planned by WWE's [[List of World Wrestling Entertainment employees#Creative writers|script writers]]. The event starred [[List of World Wrestling Entertainment employees|wrestlers]] from the [[WWE Raw|Raw]] [[WWE Brand Extension|brand]]: a storyline expansion of the promotion where employees are assigned to a wrestling brand under the WWE banner.

The [[main event]] was a [[Hell in a Cell]] match, a match where wrestlers fight in a ring surrounded by a steel structure of metal, featuring wrestlers fighting in a ring surrounded by a steel structure of metal. Triple H ([[Triple H|Paul Levesque]]) defeated Shawn Michaels ([[Shawn Michaels|Michael Hickenbottom]]) by pinfall after two consecutive [[Facebuster#Double underhook facebuster|Pedigrees]]. Two featured bouts were featured on the [[undercard]]. In respective [[Professional wrestling match types#Variations of singles matches|standard wrestling matches]],  [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)|World Heavyweight Champion]] [[Chris Benoit]] defeated Kane ([[Glen Jacobs]]) to retain his championship and [[Randy Orton]] defeated [[Shelton Benjamin]] to retain the [[WWE Intercontinental Championship]].

Including the scripted buildup, Bad Blood (2004) grossed over [[United States dollar|$]]494,000 ticket sales from an attendance of 9,000. When the event was released on [[DVD]], it reached a peak position of third on ''[[Billboard]]'s'' DVD Sales Chart.

==Background==
[[Image:Triple H Pointing Melbourne 10.11.2007.jpg|thumb|left|195px|Triple H, who faced off against Shawn Michaels in a Hell in a Cell match]]
The [[main event]] at Bad Blood was fought in a [[Hell in a Cell]] between Triple H ([[Triple H|Paul Levesque]]) and Shawn Michaels ([[Shawn Michaels|Michael Hickenbottom]]). The buildup to the match began after [[Backlash (2004)|Backlash]], WWE's previous pay-per-view event. On the May 3 edition of ''[[WWE Raw|Raw]]'', [[Professional wrestling authority figures#General managers|authority figure]] [[Eric Bischoff]], a portrayed match maker and rules enforcer, booked a [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)|World Heavyweight Championship]] match, for that episode, between World Heavyweight champion [[Chris Benoit]] and Shawn Michaels.<ref name="OWW - May 3">{{cite web|url=http://onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/040503.html|title=RAW results - May 3, 2004|accessdate=2008-02-28|publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref><ref name="411 - May 3">{{cite web|author=PK|url=http://www.411mania.com/wrestling/tv_reports/30786/411s-WWE-Raw-Report-05.03.04.htm|title=411's WWE Raw Report 05.03.04|accessdate=2008-02-28|date=2004-05-03|publisher=411mania.com}}</ref> The title match saw Benoit successfully retain the World Heavyweight championship, after interference by Triple H, one of the opponents in the Triple Threat match at Backlash. Triple H managed to perform a [[Facebuster#Double underhook facebuster|Pedigree]] on both Benoit and Michaels, which led to Triple H stagger Benoit's arm to pin Michaels.<ref name="OWW - May 3"/><ref name="411 - May 3"/> On the May 10 edition of ''Raw'', Bischoff granted Triple H a World Heavyweight championship match the following week.<ref name="OWW - May 10">{{cite web|url=http://onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/040510.html|title=RAW results - May 10, 2004|accessdate=2008-02-28|publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref><ref name="411 - May 10">{{cite web|first=Dave|last=Gagnon|url=http://www.411mania.com/wrestling/tv_reports/30789/411s-WWE-Raw-Report-05.10.04.htm|title=411's WWE Raw Report 05.10.04|accessdate=2008-02-28|date=2004-05-10|publisher=411mania.com}}</ref> That same night, a match was scheduled between [[Shelton Benjamin]] and Triple H. The match resulted in Michaels attacking Triple H, ultimately resulting in Bischoff suspending Michaels for his actions.<ref name="OWW - May 10"/><ref name="411 - May 10"/> The following week, a Number One contender's [[Battle royal (professional wrestling)|Battle Royal]] match was scheduled, in which the winner would go on to face Chris Benoit for the World Heavyweight championship at Bad Blood.<ref name="OWW - May 17">{{cite web|url=http://onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/040517.html|title=RAW results - May 17, 2004|accessdate=2008-02-28|publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref><ref name="411 - May 17">{{cite web|author=PK|url=http://www.411mania.com/wrestling/tv_reports/30792/411s-WWE-Raw-Report-05.17.04.htm|title=411's WWE Raw Report 05.17.04|accessdate=2008-02-28|date=2004-05-17|publisher=411mania.com}}</ref> One of the participants in the match included Triple H, who after eliminating Shelton Benjamin, was eliminated by Michaels, who was not a participant in the match, as he [[Professional wrestling attacks#Clothesline|clotheslined]] Triple H out of the match.<ref name="OWW - May 17"/><ref name="411 - May 17"/> On the May 24 edition of ''Raw'', Triple H pleaded with Bischoff to lift Michaels suspension and reinstate him back in the roster.<ref name="OWW - May 24">{{cite web|url=http://onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/040524.html|title=RAW results - May 24, 2004|accessdate=2008-02-28|publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref><ref name="411 - May 24">{{cite web|first=Dave|last=Gagnon|url=http://www.411mania.com/wrestling/tv_reports/30794/411s-WWE-RAW-Report-05.24.04.htm|title=411's WWE RAW Report 05.24.04|accessdate=2008-02-28|date=2004-05-24|publisher=411mania.com}}</ref> On the same evening, Michaels confronted Bischoff if he was scheduled in a match with Triple H at Bad Blood, in which Bischoff assured Michaels the match that would take place. Moment afterwards, Michaels was jumped from behind by Triple H, after Michaels attacked Triple H earlier.<ref name="OWW - May 24"/><ref name="411 - May 24"/> Bischoff gave orders to Raw superstars to attack Triple H and Michaels, if seen fighting.<ref name="OWW - May 24"/><ref name="411 - May 24"/> The roster tried breaking the fight up, but were unsuccessful in doing so.<ref name="OWW - May 24"/><ref name="411 - May 24"/>  The result of the fight gave Bischoff the authority to schedule Triple H and Michaels in a Hell in a Cell match at Bad Blood.<ref name="OWW - May 24"/><ref name="411 - May 24"/>

One of the featured [[undercard|preliminary]] matches was contested for the World Heavyweight Championship, in which Chris Benoit defended the championship against Kane. On the May 17 edition of ''Raw'', Kane won a twenty man battle royal to receive a World Heavyweight Championship title shot against Chris Benoit at Bad Blood.<ref name="OWW - May 17"/><ref name="411 - May 17"/> The following week, Kane [[Promo (professional wrestling)|revealed]] that he envied Benoit for having the World Heavyweight championship and concluded that he would get the World Heavyweight.<ref name="411 - May 24"/><ref name="May 24">{{cite web|url=http://pwwew.net/tv/raw/040524.htm|title=Enough is Enough|accessdate=2008-08-18|date=2004-05-24|publisher=PWWEW.net}}</ref> On the May 31 edition of ''Raw'', Kane was scheduled in a match against Eugene ([[Nick Dinsmore]]). The match ended in a disqualification, after Kane hit Eugene with a [[folding chair|steel chair]].<ref name="May 31">{{cite web|url=http://pwwew.net/tv/raw/040531.htm|title=Eugene! Eugene! Eugene!|accessdate=2008-08-18|date=2004-05-31|publisher=PWWEW.net}}</ref><ref name="May 31, 2004">{{cite web|url=http://onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/040531.html|title=RAW results - May 31, 2004|accessdate=2008-08-18|publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> After the match ended, Kane performed a [[chokeslam]], when a wrestler grasps their opponent's neck, lifts them up, and slams them to the mat, on Eugene, which prompted Kane to set him up for a [[Piledriver (professional wrestling)#Tombstone Piledriver|belly-to-belly piledriver]]. Benoit, however, made the save.<ref name="May 31"/><ref name="May 31, 2004"/> The following week on ''Raw'', a handicap match was scheduled between Benoit and Edge ([[Adam Copeland]]) facing off against [[La Résistance (professional wrestling)|La Résistance]] ([[Sylvain Grenier]] and Robért Conway <nowiki>[</nowiki>[[Rob Conway]]<nowiki>]</nowiki>) and Kane. The match saw Kane perform a chokeslam on Benoit, thus pinning Benoit for the win.<ref name="June 7">{{cite web|url=http://pwwew.net/tv/raw/040607.htm|title=The stage is set for Bad Blood|accessdate=2008-08-18|date=2004-06-07|publisher=PWWEW.net}}</ref><ref name="June 7, 2004">{{cite web|url=http://onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/040607.html|title=RAW results - June 7, 2004|accessdate=2008-08-18|publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref>

[[Image:Orton-ic-champion@commons.jpg|thumb|right|175px|Randy Orton as WWE Intercontinental Champion]]
The other featured preliminary match was [[Randy Orton]] versus Shelton Benjamin in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Variations of singles matches|singles match]] for Orton's [[WWE Intercontinental Championship|Intercontinental Championship]]. On the May 17 edition of ''Raw'', Randy Orton, who was a [[List of professional wrestling slang#H|heel]], a bad guy, bragged about how  he was the company's longest reigning Intercontinental champion in the last seven years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/titlehistory/intercontinental/322760|title=Randy Orton's reign as Intercontinental Championship|accessdate=2008-08-18|publisher=WWE}}</ref> Shelton Benjamin interrupted Orton's speech and challenged Orton to an Intercontinental championship match. The challenge, however, was denied by Orton, in which prompted Benjamin to attack Orton.<ref name="OWW - May 17"/><ref name="411 - May 17"/> The following week, Orton was a guest in Chris Jericho's  ([[Chris Jericho|Christopher Irvine]]) segment, ''[[WWE Raw#Recurring segments|The Highlight Reel]]''. In the segment, Orton stayed true to his word, saying that he would not grant Benjamin an Intercontinental title match. This led to Orton turning his attention towards Jericho and stating that he would enjoy adding Jericho to the list of legends that he has killed off, prior to Orton defeating legends in a "Legend versus Legend Killer" match.<ref name="411 - May 24"/><ref name="May 24"/> An all-out brawl quickly ensued between Jericho and Orton. The brawl brought out fellow Evolution member Batista ([[Dave Batista|David Bautista, Jr.]]), as he ran down to make it two on one. Benjamin also made his way to the ring and evened the sides. Bischoff announced that the battling that took place, would become in the form of a tag team encounter. The match saw the team of Benjamin and Jericho defeat Orton and Batista.<ref name="411 - May 24"/><ref name="May 24"/> On the May 31 edition of ''Raw'', it was announced that Orton would defend the Intercontinental championship against Benjamin at Bad Blood.<ref name="May 31"/><ref name="May 31, 2004"/> That same episode, Orton faced Benjamin in a non-title match, in which Benjamin got the win over Orton.<ref name="May 31"/><ref name="May 31, 2004"/> The following week on ''Raw'', a match was booked between Benjamin and Batista. During the match, Orton came to ringside and distracted Benjamin, the distraction led to Batista performing a [[Powerbomb#Sitout powerbomb|sitdown powerbomb]], in which the wrestler drops into a sitting position as they slam their opponent down to the mat, and gaining the pinfall victory over Benjamin. After the match, all three members of Evolution triple-teamed Benjamin, with Orton finishing the assault, as he hit Benjamin with the title to the face.<ref name="June 7"/><ref name="June 7, 2004"/>

==Event==
Before the event went live on pay-per-view, Batista defeated Maven ([[Maven Huffman]]) in a match taped for ''[[WWE Heat|Heat]]'', one of WWE's secondary television programs.<ref name="hoffco">{{cite web|url=http://www.hoffco-inc.com/wwe/ppv/ppv/bb04.html|title=Bad Blood 2004|accessdate=2008-08-18|publisher=Hoffco, Inc.}}</ref>

===Preliminary matches===
[[Image:Shelton Benjamin.jpg|thumb|right|Shelton Benjamin, who faced off against Randy Orton for the Intercontinental Championship]]
After ''Sunday Night Heat'', the pay-per-view began with a tag team match for the [[World Tag Team Championship (WWE)|World Tag Team Championship]], where La Résistance (Sylvain Grenier and Robért Conway) defended the titles against Chris Benoit and Edge. La Résistance gained the early advantage when Conway grabbed Edge and rammed him onto the security wall, back first. Conway then rolled Edge back into the ring, in which Grenier dragged Edge to the corner, where Conway was standing, and double teamed Edge. The advantage was gained back by Edge, when he knocked Grenier with a [[Professional wrestling attacks#Spinning heel kick|spinning heel kick]]. Edge tagged Benoit into the match, which led him to get the advantage over Grenier and Conway. Benoit inserted Grenier in an [[Professional wrestling holds#Crossface|arm trap crossface]]. Kane's pyrotechnics went off and made his way to the ring, as he entered the ring he hit Benoit with a big boot knocking him down and the referee ending the match in a [[Professional wrestling#Disqualification|disqualification]], thus La Résistance retaining the World Tag Team titles.<ref name="PWWEW - Bad Blood"/><ref name="Bad Blood">{{cite web|first=Jason|last=Clevett|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/PPVReports/2004/06/14/499219.html|title= Badd Blood a total bore|aaccessdate=2008-01-21|date=2004-06-14|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]|work=SLAM! Sports}}</ref>

The second wrestling match on the pay-per-view was Tyson Tomko ([[Travis Tomko]]) (with Trish Stratus <nowiki>[</nowiki>[[Trish Stratus|Patricia Stratigias]]<nowiki>]</nowiki>) versus Chris Jericho in a standard match. In the early stages both competitors wrestled inconclusively, reversed each other's attacks, before Tyson backed Jericho into a corner and hit numerous reverse elbows. Afterwards, Jericho went for a [[Moonsault#Springboard moonsault|middle rope springboard moonsault]], but Tomko rolled out of the way, sending Jericho to crash down to the mat. The match concluded with Jericho performing [[Professional wrestling attacks#Enzuigiri|an attack that struck the back of Tyson's head]] and pinning Tomko for the three count.<ref name="PWWEW - Bad Blood"/><ref name="Bad Blood"/>

The next match was a standard match for the [[WWE Intercontinental Championship]], in which Randy Orton defended the title against Shelton Benjamin. The match began with Benjamin performing a [[drop kick]] on Orton, which knocked him out to the outside of the ring. Benjamin proceeded to knock Orton over the security wall into the crowd. Orton got the advantage, after Ric Flair made his way to the ring, distracting Benjamin in the process. Back and forth action took place between Orton and Benjamin. The match came to an end when Benjamin went off the top rope and came with a cross body, but Orton rolled through and hooked Benjamin's tights to pin Benjamin for the three count and retaining the Intercontinental title.<ref name="PWWEW - Bad Blood"/><ref name="Bad Blood"/>

===Main event matches===
[[Image:Victoriachampion.jpg|thumb|left|Victoria as WWE Women's Champion]]
The first featured preliminary match was a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic non-elimination matches|fatal four-way match]] for the [[WWE Women's Championship]], in which Victoria ([[Lisa Marie Varon]]) defended the title against Trish Stratus, Lita ([[Amy Dumas]]), and [[Gail Kim]]. The start of the match saw Victoria and Lita double team Stratus, but Stratus rolled out of the ring. Lita and Victoria went on to double team Kim, however, Stratus pulled Lita out of the ring, which left Victoria to perform a move in which Victoria [[Moonsault#Standing moonsault|stood next to Kim lying on the ground and executed a backflip and landed on her]]. The match was controlled by Victoria, Stratus, Lita, and Kim in several spots in the match. Lita performed a [[DDT (professional wrestling)|move in which Kim fell down which drove her head into the mat]], as Lita went for the pin, Stratus rolled Lita up for the pinfall victory, thus Stratus' becoming Women's champion for a fifth time.<ref name="Bad Blood"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/titlehistory/women/3044541321211122|title=Trish Stratus' fifth reign as WWE Women's Champion|accessdate=2008-08-18|publisher=WWE}}</ref>

The fifth match was between Eugene and [[Jonathan Coachman]] in a singles match. The match started with Eugene hitting an arm drag on Coachman and hitting numerous headbutts. An unknown woman in a bikini came out to the ringside area with some cookies, Coachman offered cookies to Eugene. The woman lured Eugene out of the ring and Eugene went over and grabbed some cookies. As Eugene went to grab more cookies, Coachman slammed Eugene's head into the cookie tray. A spot in the match saw Garrison Cade ([[Lance Cade|Lance McNaught]]) come out to ringside with a stuffed animal, which prompted Cade to tore up toy animal. Cade tried to hold Eugene so Coachman could get the advantage, however, Eugene was able dodge the attack, as Coachman ended up hitting Cade instead. Eugene grabbed Coachman and performed a [[Powerslam#Side slam|variation which sees Eugene hook Coachman's leg in order to lift him easier]] and a [[Feint]] [[leg drop]] transitioned into an [[Elbow drop#Elbow drop|elbow drop]] to the [[chest]], with theatrics. Eugene pinned Coachman for the three count for the win.<ref name="PWWEW - Bad Blood"/><ref name="Bad Blood"/>

The featured preliminary match was for the World Heavyweight Championship, in which Chris Benoit defended the title against Kane. Benoit started the match by hitting Kane numerous times with [[Professional wrestling attacks#Backhand chop|backhand chops]], a wrestler slaping the chest of his opponent with the palm of the hand using a backhand swing. Mid-way in the match, Benoit charged towards Kane, but Kane hit a [[Powerslam#Sidewalk slam|sidewalk slam]], where a wrestler stands side-to-side and slightly behind with the victim, facing in the same direction, and reaches around the victim's torso with his near arm across the victim's chest and under both arms and places the other arm under the victim's legs him and tossed him over the top rope to the arena floor, Kane then stepped out of the ring and grabbed Benoit, in which he wanted to launch Benoit into the ring post, but Benoit was able to reverse Kane's attack and slammed him into the ring post. After blocking an arm trap crossface attempt, Kane [[chokeslam|lifted Benoit by the throat and slammed him down to the mat]] for a two count. The match concluded with Kane headed to the top rope and coming off to perform a [[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#Flying clothesline|flying clothesline]], a move in which a wrestler will jump from an elevated position and perform a [[clothesline]] to a standing opponent, but Benoit went for another arm trap crossface, but Kane fought out of and Benoit rolled Kane up in a pin to get a three count, and thus retaining the World Heavyweight title.<ref name="PWWEW - Bad Blood"/><ref name="Bad Blood"/>

[[Image:Shawn Michaels at WrestleMania XXIV.jpg|thumb|right|155px|Shawn Michaels, who was scheduled in a Hell in a Cell match against Triple H]]
The main event was the Hell in a Cell match between Shawn Michaels and Triple H. The match began with Michaels hitting a [[Professional wrestling attacks#Lou Thesz press|Lou Thesz press]], a move in which it sees the attacking wrestler jump towards a standing opponent and knock him over, resulting in the opponent lying on his back with the attacking wrestler sitting on the opponent's chest, pinning him in a [[Professional wrestling holds#Body scissors|body scissors]]. This was followed with Michaels' slamming Triple H's head onto the steel cage, resulting in Triple H bleeding from the forehead. Triple H got the advantage, as he was able to counter a  [[Piledriver (professional wrestling)|Piledriver]], a move in which the wrestler grabs his opponent, turns him upside-down, and drops into a sitting or kneeling position, driving the opponent's head into the mat, and performed a back body drop on Michaels. Another attack saw Triple H bring the steel steps and nail Michaels with it, which resulted in Michaels bleeding from the forehead. A spot in the match saw Michaels lay Triple H in a table, as he climbed onto a [[ladder]] he took out from under the ring, and performed a [[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#Diving elbow drop|diving elbow drop]] by diving onto Triple H and driving the elbow into his chest, thus breaking the table in the process. Following the spot, Triple H gained the advantage and [[Facebuster#Double underhook facebuster|tucked Michaels' head between his knees and lifted them up to slam Michaels' head to the mat]], twice, a move that Triple H calls the ''Pedigree''. Triple H covered Michaels for the win via pinfall.<ref name="PWWEW - Bad Blood"/><ref name="Bad Blood"/>  After the match, Michaels staggered to his feet and was given a standing ovation by the audience.<ref name="PWWEW - Bad Blood"/><ref name="Bad Blood"/>

==Aftermath==
Following Bad Blood, Raw [[WWE Raw#Commentators|commentator]] [[Jim Ross]] tried making amends between Shawn Michaels and Triple H by making them shake hands. Michaels and Triple H extended their hands to shake, but Kane came out and attacked Michaels, which resulted in Kane [[kayfabe|crushing]] Michaels [[larynx|throat]] with a wedged chair.<ref name="June 14">{{cite web|url=http://pwwew.net/tv/raw/040614.htm|title=Evolution Outlasted|accessdate=2008-01-16|date=2004-06-14|publisher=PWWEW.net}}</ref> Michaels was then taken out in an ambulance for medical attention.<ref name="June 14"/> That same episode, Lita revealed that she was pregnant. On the June 21 episode of ''Raw'', it appeared that Lita's, boyfriend at that time, [[Matt Hardy]] was going to propose to Lita, but he was interrupted by Kane, who claimed to be the father of Lita's child, as Lita had slept with Kane to persuade him to stop attacking Hardy.<ref name="June 21"/><ref name="June 21, 2004"/> Two months later, it was revealed that Kane was, in fact, the father.<ref name="August 9">{{cite web|url=http://pwwew.net/tv/raw/040809.htm|title=Crippling Circumstances|accessdate=2008-08-19|date=2004-08-09|publisher=PWWEW.net}}</ref><ref name="August 9, 2004">{{cite web|url=http://onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/040809.html|title=RAW results - August 9, 2004|accessdate=2008-08-19|publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> Hardy and Kane feuded for several months, culminating in a "Till Death Do Us Part" match  at [[SummerSlam (2004)|SummerSlam]], with the stipulation that Lita would be obliged to marry Kane should Hardy lose.<ref name="August 9"/><ref name="August 9, 2004"/> Kane won the match,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/summerslam07/history/2004/results/|title=SummerSlam 2004 results|accessdate=2008-08-19|publisher=WWE}}</ref> leading to he and a reluctant Lita marrying one another on the August 23 episode of ''Raw''.<ref name="August 23">{{cite web|url= http://pwwew.net/tv/raw/040823.htm|title=THE WEDDING BELL TOLLS|accessdate=2008-01-15|date=2004-08-23|publisher=PWWEW.net}}</ref><ref name="August 23, 2004">{{cite web|url=http://onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/040823.html|title=RAW results - August 23, 2004|accessdate=2008-08-19|publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> On the August 30 edition of ''Raw'', Kane stated that Eric Bischoff's wedding gift to him and Lita was to name any match he wanted for [[Unforgiven (2004)|Unforgiven]].<ref name="August 30">{{cite web|url=http://pwwew.net/tv/raw/040830.htm|title=Orton becomes the Hunter| accessdate=2008-01-16|date=2004-08-30|publisher=PWWEW.net}}</ref><ref name="August 30, 2004">{{cite web|url=http://onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/040830.html|title=RAW results - August 30, 2004|accessdate=2008-08-19|publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> Lita then informed Kane that Bischoff's present was for ''both'' of them, where they were able to pick Kane's opponent for Unforgiven, which resulted in Shawn Michaels being picked.<ref name="August 30"/><ref name="August 30, 2004"/> At Unforgiven, Michaels defeated Kane in a [[Professional wrestling match types#No Disqualification match|No Disqualification match]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Chris|last=Sokol|url= http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/PPVReports/2004/09/13/788802.html|title=Unforgiven a good night for HHH|accessdate=2008-01-15|date=2004-09-13|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]|work=SLAM! Sports}}</ref>

Eric Bischoff informed Triple H that if he could defeat Eugene, for the following week's episode, that he would be Number one contender to face Chris Benoit for the World Heavyweight title.<ref name="June 14">{{cite web|first=Nathan|last=Fleck|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/results/raw/raw2004/1087271111.shtml|title=Full WWE RAW Results - 6/14/04|accessdate=2008-08-18|date=2004-06-14|publisher=WrestleView.com}}</ref><ref name="June 14, 2004">{{cite web|url=http://onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/040614.html|title=RAW results - June 14, 2004|accessdate=2008-08-18|publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> The following week on ''Raw'', the match between Triple H and Eugene ended in a No Contest, after Chris Benoit ran down to save Eugene from a chair assault by Triple H.<ref name="June 21">{{cite web|url=http://pwwew.net/tv/raw/040621.htm|title=With friends like these...|accessdate=2008-08-18|date=2004-06-21|publisher=PWWEW.net}}</ref><ref name="June 21, 2004">{{cite web|url=http://onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/040621.html|title=RAW results - June 21, 2004|accessdate=2008-08-18|publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> On the June 28 edition of ''Raw'', a rematch for the World Heavyweight championship between Benoit and Kane took place. A stipulation was placed that Benoit had to win the match by a submission, as Kane could win by pinfall, submission, disqualification or count out.<ref name="June 28">{{cite web|url=http://pwwew.net/tv/raw/040628.htm|title=Stacked Deck|accessdate=2008-08-18|date=2004-06-28|publisher=PWWEW.net}}</ref><ref name="June 28, 2004">{{cite web|url=http://onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/040628.html|title=RAW results - June 28, 2004|accessdate=2008-08-18|publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> It was also announced that the winner of the match would face Triple H at [[Vengeance (2004)|Vengeance]], in which the World Heavyweight title would be on the line.<ref name="June 28"/><ref name="June 28, 2004"/> Benoit won the match, after he made Kane submit to an arm trap crossface.<ref name="June 28"/><ref name="June 28, 2004"/> The following week, Bischoff scheduled a handicap match between Triple H, Ric Flair and Eugene versus Benoit and Edge. The match was won by Triple H, after Eugene hit Benoit with a steel chair and Triple H pinning Benoit for the win for his team.<ref name="July 5">{{cite web|url=http://pwwew.net/tv/raw/040705.htm|title=Special Night|accessdate=2008-08-18|date=2004-07-05|publisher=PWWEW.net}}</ref><ref name="July 5, 2004">{{cite web|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/040705.html|title=RAW results - July 5, 2004|accessdate=2008-08-18|publisher=Online World of Wrestling}}</ref> At Vengeance, Benoit defeated Triple H to retain the World Heavyweight title.<ref name="Vengeance">{{cite web|url=http://pwwew.net/ppv/wwf/july/2004.htm|title=Vengeance 2004 Results|accessdate=2008-08-18|publisher=PWWEW.net}}</ref>

On the June 21 edition of ''Raw'', a confrontation between Randy Orton and The Rock ([[Dwayne Johnson]]) took place. After the Rock assaulted Orton, Bischoff sent security guards to escort the Rock out of the arena. Orton demanded that they stop playing the Rock's theme music. Edge, however, sneaked behind Orton and [[Professional wrestling attacks#Spear|speared]] him.<ref name="June 21"/><ref name="June 21, 2004"/> That same episode, a tag team match was booked between Edge and Chris Jericho versus Orton and Batista. During the match, Jericho took a shot to the head and was unconscious as they went to commercial break. Several referees went to ringside, and took Jericho to the back, leaving Edge by himself against Orton and Batista. The match saw the team of Orton and Batista defeat Edge.<ref name="June 21"/><ref name="June 21, 2004"/> The following week, it was announced that Orton would defend the Intercontinental championship against Edge at Vengeance.<ref name="June 28"/><ref name="June 28, 2004"/> Later that night, per the week before, a similar tag team match between Orton and Batista versus Edge and Jericho took place. This time, Edge and Jericho won the match, after Batista accidentally hit Orton with a [[Professional wrestling attacks#Lariat|lariat]] and Edge spearing Batista, thus allowing Jericho to pin Batista for the win.<ref name="June 28"/><ref name="June 28, 2004"/> At Vengeance, Orton lost the Intercontinental title to Edge.<ref>{{cite web|first=Chris|last=Sokol|url= http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/PPVReports/2004/07/12/537080.html|title=Canadians have Edge at Vengeance|accessdate=2008-02-02|date=2004-07-12|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]|work=SLAM! Sports}}</ref>

===Reception===
The Nationwide Arena has a maximum capacity of 19,500.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buyselltix.com/nhl/stadium/bluejacketsStadium.php|title=Nationwide Arena: Columbus Blue Jacket Stadium|accessdate=2008-08-19|publisher=BuySellTix}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hockeyarenas.com/stadien/columbus/nationwidearenaenglish.htm|title=The Nationwide Arena in Columbus, Ohio|accessdate=2008-08-19|publisher=Hockey Arenas}}</ref> The event grossed over $494,000 in ticket sales from an attendance of 9,000.<ref name="pwh"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://corporate.wwe.com/investors/documents/Q1F2006EarningsRelease_000.pdf|title=World Wrestling Entertainment, Inc. Reports Q1 Results|accessdate=2008-08-19|date=2005-09-07|publisher=[[World Wrestling Entertainment]] Corporation}}</ref> ''[[Canadian Online Explorer]]'s'' professional wrestling section rated the entire event a five out of ten stars.<ref name="Bad Blood"/> The rating was higher than the [[Bad Blood (2003)|Bad Blood event in 2003]], which rated a four out ten stars.<ref>{{cite web|first=John|last=Powell|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2003/06/16/112594.html|title=Bad Blood just plain bad|accessdate=2008-08-19|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]|work=SLAM! Sports}}</ref> The World Heavyweight championship match between Chris Benoit and Kane was rated an eight out of ten stars.<ref name="Bad Blood"/> The match between Eugene and Jonathan Coachman was rated zero out of ten stars.<ref name="Bad Blood"/>

The event was released on [[DVD]] on July 13, 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fye.com/WWE-Raw--Bad-Blood-WWE_stcVVproductId2694764VVcatId540232VVviewprod.htm|title=WWE Bad Blood DVD at F.Y.E|accessdate=2008-08-19|publisher=[[For Your Entertainment]]}}</ref> The DVD was distributed by the label, [[Sony Music Entertainment]]. The DVD reached third on ''[[Billboard]]'s'' DVD Sales Chart for recreational sports during the week of August 28, 2004, although falling thereafter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/esearch/chart_display.jsp?cfi=394&cfgn=Videos&cfn=Video+Sales+-+Recreational+Sports+DVD&ci=3054858&cdi=8190140&cid=08%2F07%2F2004|title=Bad Blood 2004 DVD Sales|accessdate=2008-08-19|work=[[Billboard]]}}</ref>  It remained in the chart for two consecutive weeks, until the week of September 25, 2004, when it ranked 19th.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/esearch/chart_display.jsp?cfi=394&cfgn=Videos&cfn=Video+Sales+-+Recreational+Sports+DVD&ci=3055446&cdi=8211768&cid=09%2F25%2F2004|title=Bad Blood 2004 DVD Sales|accessdate=2008-08-19|work=[[Billboard]]}}</ref> The DVD also received reviews from customers; the average customer rating from [[Amazon.com]] was four out of five stars.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.com/WWE-Blood-2004-Randy-Orton/dp/B00028G6U8/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&s=dvd&qid=1219106319&sr=1-1|title=Bad Blood 2004 DVD Sales at Amazon.com|accessdate=2008-08-19|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]}}</ref>

text:
'''Skewball''' was the name of a British [[racehorse]], most famous as the subject of a [[ballad]]. The horse was born in 1741, and originally owned by Francis, 2nd [[Earl of Godolphin]], and later sold. His name has been recorded as "Squball", "Sku-ball", or "'''Stewball'''". He won many races in England, and a famous one in Ireland, which is generally the subject of the song of the same name. Popular legend has Skewball belonging to an Arthur Marvell. Based on the horse's name, Skewball was likely a [[skewbald]] horse, though there is speculation that he was a [[Bay (color)|bay]]. 

==Songs==
There are two major different versions of the [[Sporting song|sporting ballad]], generally titled either "Skewball" or "Stewball"; the latter is more popular in America.  There are multiple variations within the two major divisions.  Versions date at least as far back as the 18th century, appearing on numerous [[broadside (music)|broadsides]].  In both songs the title horse is the underdog in the race, up against a favored grey mare (usually called either "Griselda" or "Molly"), and although in most versions of Stewball the winning horse triumphs due to the stumbling of the lead horse, Skewball wins simply by being the faster horse in the end.  Probably the most significant lyrical difference in the songs is the conversation Skewball has with his jockey, while Stewball behaves more like a typical horse and does not speak. 

American versions were sung and adapted by slaves in the Southern United States, and have Stewball racing in [[California]], [[Texas]], and [[Kentucky]].  British versions, when the setting is mentioned, often place the race in [[Kildare]], [[Ireland]], leading some to believe that the song is actually Irish in origin.  The fact that these accounts still imply that the horse's nationality was English, and they celebrate a victory over a horse that is presumably Irish, makes it likely the song is originally English, and its setting in Ireland is due to it being the site of Skewball's most famous race.

==Recordings==

"...comes aprancin' and adancin' my darling Stewball."

A notable recording is by American folk legend [[Woody Guthrie]], who included an English and an American interpretation (both entitled Stewball) on tape and recorded in Volume 4 of [[The Asch Recordings]] ([[1930]]-[[1940]]).  The American interpretation is sung with an African American '[[call and response (music)|call and response]]' style while the English interpretation has a more traditional folk style. The American interpretation has Stewball as being born in California with the famed race against the grey mare taking place in [[Dallas, Texas]].  This version of the song was popularized by Texas singer/songwriter [[Robert Earl Keen]], in [[The Live Album]] performance at Dallas's [[Sons of Hermann Hall]].

Another notable version of "Stewball" was recorded by [[John Herald]] and the [[Greenbriar Boys]], and popularized by [[Peter, Paul and Mary]]. [[The Weavers]] and [[Lonnie Donegan]] recorded it in the 1950s. Other versions include [[Joan Baez]]' on ''[[Joan Baez/5]]'' (1964) and [[The Hollies]] on [[Would You Believe]] (1966). The 1971 [[John Lennon]] song "[[Happy Xmas (War Is Over)]]" has a similar meter and tune [http://www.icce.rug.nl/~soundscapes/VOLUME01/Baroque_Folk_Lennon.html]. Popular British versions include recordings by [[A. L. Lloyd]], [[Martin Carthy]], and [[Steeleye Span]] on the album ''[[Ten Man Mop, or Mr. Reservoir Butler Rides Again]]''.  An American version following the British tradition is recorded by [[Broadside Electric]] on [[Black-edged Visiting Card]].  

Additionally, a [[French language|French]] cover has been recorded by [[Hugues Aufray]], becoming one of Aufray's biggest hits. However, this version is unlike the English versions. Aufray's version of the song takes the perspective of a man recalling an experience as a ten-year old boy. His father believes that Stewball will win a race, so he puts all his money and assets into this venture. Toward the end of the race, Stewball tragically falls. The veterinarian finishes him off with a single shot.  This is the first time that the narrator witnesses his father cry.
Aufray's version is very different from other interpretations in that it features Stewball not winning his race and dying due to an injury.
