{{infobox brand | name = Playtex | logo = [[File:Playtex-logo.png|200px]] | image = [[File:Playtex bra logo.png|200px]] | caption = Playtex Products logo (top),
Playtex Apparel logo | type = Feminine care/baby care/intimate apparel | currentowner = Playtex Marketing Corp. | origin = U.S. | introduced = 1947 | discontinued = | related = [[Hawaiian Tropic]] | markets = | previousowners = International Latex Corp., Playtex Products Inc. | trademarkregistrations = U.S., Canada | ambassadors = | tagline = Making Every Day Better (feminine and infant care),
Who Knows You Like We Do? (bras) | website = [http://www.playtex.com/ PLAYTEX] }} '''Playtex''' is a product brand owned by Playtex Marketing Corp. and leased to several companies that sell Playtex-branded products. [[Sara Lee Corporation|Sara Lee]] has exclusive rights to the Playtex brand for bras, panties and [[Foundation garment|shapewear]] in Europe and South Africa, while a [[HanesBrands]] subsidiary sells Playtex apparel in the rest of the world. Playtex Products LLC, which is owned by Energizer Holdings, sells Playtex-branded baby cups, gloves, [[tampon]]s and other consumer products. Prior to 1988 all Playtex-branded products were sold by a single company. Playtex was founded as International Latex Corporation (ILC), which started out making infants' [[rubber pants]] in the 1930s, before expanding into women's girdles. After World War II, ILC resumed production and created Playtex as one of four divisions. Playtex established the use of standard sizes for undergarments, while previously they were custom-tailored. The company was the first to advertise undergarments on national television in 1955. Twenty-two years later, it was also the first to take advantage of relaxed regulations by the [[National Association of Broadcasters]], when it showed a live model wearing a bra in a commercial. During the 1960s, [[tampon]]s and infant-care products bearing the Playtex brand were introduced, making Playtex the primary competitor to [[Tampax]] in the tampon [[Economic sector|sector]]. Playtex also introduced the plastic tampon applicator. In 1962, before Playtex's industrial division spun-off into [[ILC Dover]], it helped create the latex components of the spacesuits used in the Apollo mission. From 1969 to the 1990s, [[chief executive officer]] Joel Smilow led the company through a series of acquisitions and sales. Playtex was acquired by [[Esmark]] in 1975, and then by [[Beatrice Foods]] in 1985. A year later an investor group led by Smilow bought Playtex for $1.25 billion. Its cosmetics brands were sold to [[Revlon]] to fund the acquisition. In 1988, Smilow split Playtex into two companies in a $1.3 billion transaction that bought out some of Playtex's other investors and put ownership into two separate investment firms operated by Smilow. In 1991, Playtex Apparel Inc., was sold to [[Sara Lee Corporation]], which became part of [[Energizer Holdings]] in 2007. Several of Sara Lee's brands, including Playtex Apparel, were spun-off into [[HanesBrands]]. == History == ===Early history=== Abram Nathaniel Spanel founded Playtex's predecessor, the International Latex Corporation (ILC), in 1932{{cite book|author=Joey Green|title=Joey Green's Cleaning Magic: 2,336 Ingenious Cleanups Using Brand-Name Products|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=vK0JiztOpVEC&pg=PA167|accessdate=7 December 2012|date=6 July 2010|publisher=Rodale|isbn=978-1-60529-745-3|pages=167–}} to produce latex products,{{cite journal|last1=Weitekamp|first1=Margaret A.|title=Technology: The spacesuit unpicked|journal=Nature|volume=475|issue=7356|year=2011|pages=294–294|issn=0028-0836|doi=10.1038/475294a}} like bathing caps, swimwear{{cite book|author=Evan Morris|title=From Altoids to Zima: The Surprising Stories Behind 125 Famous Brand Names|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9TeOf3BcOJIC&pg=PA98|accessdate=7 December 2012|date=2 November 2004|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-7432-5797-8|pages=98–}} and baby pants. ILC moved to [[Dover, Delaware]] in 1939, making it the first large, non-agricultural business in the city.{{cite book|author=Beth Rubin|title=Delaware Curiosities: Quirky Characters, Roadside Oddities & Other Offbeat Stuff|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=OXh3vp6wod0C&pg=PA53|accessdate=7 December 2012|date=1 June 2007|publisher=Globe Pequot|isbn=978-0-7627-4335-3|pages=53–}}{{cite news|title=Dover, Delaware: founded in 1683 by William Penn and named..|publisher=Healthcare Traveler|date=June 1, 2007|accessdate=December 7, 2012}} [[File:Playtex living girdle ad.jpg|thumb|left|A woman leaping while wearing a 1940s latex girdle]] ILC did not produce apparel for adults until the introduction of the Living Girdle in 1940, after [[patent]]ing a method of manufacturing latex girdles that didn't tear at the seams if they had a small tear or hole. The Living Girdle was advertised with images of mobility and comfort, such as women playing tennis or leaping while wearing it, though the solid rubber girdle was actually very uncomfortable. During [[World War II]], the bombing of [[Pearl Harbor]] and the Japanese invasion of [[Malaysia]] cut off [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] manufacturers from their largest sources of latex. As supplies ran out and demand for consumer products fell, ILC halted production; sales would not resume until 1946.{{cite book|author=Nicholas De Monchaux|title=Spacesuit: Fashioning Apollo|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=IT-chpAkCZ0C&pg=PA121|accessdate=9 December 2012|date=18 March 2011|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=978-0-262-01520-2|pages=121–}} The company almost went out of business during the war, so it created an industrial division to find government and military applications for latex.{{cite news|url=http://www.npr.org/2011/03/25/134855907/How-To-Dress-For-Space-Travel|publisher=National Public Radio|date=March 25, 2011|title=How to Dress for Space Travel|accessdate=December 9, 2012}} Playtex was founded in 1947 as one of four divisions ILC re-organized into. Its name was a [[portmanteau]] of "play" and "latex", reflecting its focus on laytex products. Playtex's marketing in the post-war era was influential in creating the shift from custom-tailored undergarments to manufactured sizes. For example, the company introduced large floor displays with fitting charts, so women could find the right size without a custom fitting. In 1954, ILC was sold to Stanley Warner Corporation for $15 million{{cite news|newspaper=The New York Times|title=STANLEY WARNER BUYS LATEX CORP.; $15,000,000 Cash Deal First for Movie Concern Outside Field of Entertainment|url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30F14FE3F5C177B93C6A9178ED85F408585F9}}(${{formatprice|{{inflation|US|15000000|1954|r=-3}}}} in modern dollars{{Inflation-fn|US}}). The following year, it was the first to advertise under-garments on network television. In 1962, the industrial division of Playtex was awarded a contract to develop space suits for the [[Apollo]] mission to the moon. Two years prior to the 1969 moon landing that used its latex suits, Playtex's industrial division was spun off, eventually becoming [[ILC Dover]]. Playtex created a consumer products subsidiary, Playtex Products Inc., in 1960,"Alph Peterson, 82, Ex-Chief Executive who Led Playtex," ''New York Times.'' February 16, 1995. which produced baby products, [[tampon]]s and other consumer goods. It introduced and patented the first plastic tampon applicator in 1973.{{cite book|author=Lafley/Charan|title=The Game Changer: How Every Leader Can Drive Everyday Innovation|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=auCt2-LPnLkC&pg=PA1975|accessdate=27 April 2013|date=3 September 2010|publisher=Profile Books|isbn=978-1-84765-136-5|pages=1975–}}''[http://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=588772453235457659& Playtex Products, Inc. v. First Quality Hygienic, Inc.]'', 965 F. Supp. 339 ([[United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York|E.D.N.Y.]], 1996) Retrieved April 30, 2013. By 1975, the five largest tampon manufacturers began competing with multi-million dollar advertising budgets and Playtex became the primary competitor to market-leader [[Tampax]].{{cite journal|title=Playtex tampon ad|journal=[[Ebony (magazine){{!}}Ebony]]|year=1977|month=August|page=24|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=08sDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA24|accessdate=April 30, 2013}} Playtex introduced a scented tampon that was advertised with the slogan, "When you're wearing a tampon you don't worry about odor. But should you?" It added a warning label saying that some women may experience irritation from the chemicals after complaints were raised by [[Planned Parenthood]].{{cite book|author=Laurie Garrett|title=The Coming Plague: Newly Emerging Diseases in a World Out of Balance|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=v9RY2PVOtOMC&pg=PT819|accessdate=30 April 2013|date=31 October 1994|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-1-4299-5327-6|pages=819–}} Tampon manufacturers, including Playtex, were sued''E.g'' ''[http://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=12592561431271918491 Ellis v. International Playtex, Inc.]'', 745 F.2d 292 ([[United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit|4th Cir.]], 1984); ''[http://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=1672540501444513356 Rinehart v. International Playtex, Inc.]'', 688 F.Supp. 475 ([[United States District Court for the Southern District of Indiana|S.D. Ind.]], 1988) and ''[http://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=5770077319332937253 Stewart v. International Playtex Inc.]'', 672 F.Supp. 907 ([[United States District Court for the District of South Carolina|D.S.C.]], 1987) for aggressively advertising and competing over absorbency, when some studies found that excessive absorbency leads to [[toxic shock syndrome]].{{cite book|author1=Alice J. Dan|author2=Linda L. Lewis|title=Menstrual Health in Women's Lives|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=1GyLgFlidSQC&pg=PA265|accessdate=7 December 2012|year=1992|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0-252-06209-4|pages=265–}}{{cite book|author=Lawrence M. Salinger|title=Encyclopedia of White-Collar & Corporate Crime|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=0f7yTNb_V3QC&pg=PA786|accessdate=7 December 2012|date=3 August 2004|publisher=SAGE|isbn=978-0-7619-3004-4|pages=786–}} In 1985, a judge offered to reduce an $11 million verdict against Playtex, if they admitted their super-plus tampons were killing women and [[product recall|recalled]] them.{{cite book|author=Janice Delaney|title=The Curse: A Cultural History of Menstruation|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=njfQfrMr31EC&pg=PA145|accessdate=30 April 2013|year=1988|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0-252-01452-9|pages=145–}} ===Joel Smilow era=== [[File:Original Playtex Logo.png|thumb|right|The Playtex logo before the brand was split among multiple companies]] Joel Smilow became [[chief executive officer]] (CEO) of Playtex in 1969{{cite news|newspaper=The Hour|date=September 14, 1988|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IuwiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hHQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4334,2243316&dq=joel+smilow+playtex+1969&hl=en|title=Refinancing announced by Playtex|accessdate=December 10, 2012}} and was associated with the company through five owners.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1988/02/17/business/655888.html|newspaper=The New York Times|first=Robert|last=Cole|date=February 17, 1988|accessdate=December 10, 2012|title=Business Day}} The company was acquired by [[Esmark]] in 1975 for $210 millionI.B. 1975, Esmark in Pact to Buy Playtex, New York, N.Y., United States, New York, N.Y.{{cite news|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=January 2, 1976|title=Rapid-American Corp. 9-Month Operations Had $5.6 Million Loss|accessdate=December 10, 2012}}(${{formatprice|{{inflation|US|210000000|1975|r=-3}}}} in modern dollars){{Inflation-fn|US}}. By the early 1980s, Playtex controlled 25 percent of the market for bras, giving it the largest market-share in the industry.{{cite book|author=New York Media, LLC|title=New York Magazine|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=KdgBAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA29|accessdate=30 April 2013|date=12 December 1983|publisher=New York Media, LLC|pages=29–|id={{ISSN|00287369}}}} In 1982 Playtex acquired the skin and hair products brand, Jhirmack Enterprises Inc., for $28.3 million.{{cite news|title=Playtex to Buy Skin Care Concern|work=The New York Times|page=4|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/04/business/playtex-to-buy-skin-care-concern.html}}(${{formatprice|{{inflation|US|28300000|1982|r=-3}}}} in modern dollars{{Inflation-fn|US}}). Three years later Esmark sold Playtex to [[Beatrice Foods]].{{cite book|author=Roy C. Smith|title=The Money Wars: The Rise & Fall of the Great Buyout Boom of the 1980s|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=2o-Avf0TqA8C&pg=PA201|accessdate=7 December 2012|date=1 May 2000|publisher=Beard Books|isbn=978-1-893122-69-7|pages=201–}} Four years later an investor group led by Smilow bought Playtex for $1.25 billion (${{formatprice|{{inflation|US|1250000000|1986|r=-3}}}} in modern dollars{{Inflation-fn|US}}). To help fund the acquisition, the company's cosmetics brands, Max Factor, Almay and Halston,{{cite news|newspaper=USA Today|title=J&J to buy Playtex units for $726M|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/USAToday/access/55805594.html?dids=55805594:55805594&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Feb+17%2C+1988&author=Jay+McCormick&pub=USA+TODAY+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=J%26J+to+buy+Playtex+units+for+%24726M&pqatl=google|first=Jay|last=McCormick|date=February 17, 1988}} were sold to [[Revlon]] for $345 million.{{cite news|last=Belkin|first=Lisa|title=Halston Finds Fashion A Fickle Mistress|accessdate=11 December 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=28 March 1987}}(${{formatprice|{{inflation|US|345000000|1988|r=-3}}}} in modern dollars{{Inflation-fn|US}}). [[File:1985 Playtex ad.png|thumb|left|150px|The semi-nude model in a 1985 advertisement that took advantage of relaxed NAB regulations]] The following year, the [[National Association of Broadcasters]] (NAB) relaxed rules regarding partial nudity on television, which previously forced undergarment manufacturers to use mannequins in their commercials, despite bathing suits and equally revealing swimwear being allowed.{{cite news|title=TV Doesn't Allow Actors in Underwear in Commercials|url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70C16FD3F5E1A7493C0A81782D85F428785F9|newspaper=The New York Times|date=September 12, 1976|accessdate=April 29, 2013}} Playtex was the first to advertise with a live model wearing only a bra from the waist up). This attracted criticisms from members of the [[American Family Association]] and the [[Eagle Forum]].{{cite book|author=Tom Reichert|title=The Erotic History of Advertising|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=-NzOYQwsL4sC&pg=PA180|accessdate=7 December 2012|year=2003|publisher=Prometheus Books|isbn=978-1-61592-336-6|pages=180–}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' called the ads, "totally inoffensive" and [[CBS]]'s spokesman said they were "well done, tasteful and not exploitative."{{cite news|last=Dougherty|first=Philip H.|title=ADVERTISING; Playtex Ads Will Show Bras on Live Models|work=The New York Times|page=19|date=22 April 1987|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/22/business/advertising-playtex-ads-will-show-bras-on-live-models.html}} Ownership of the remaining apparel and consumer products divisions were split among the company's leadership (28 percent), BCI Holdings (20 percent), [[Drexel Burnham Lambert|Drexel Burnham]] (19 percent) and institutional investors (33 percent). The following year the company attempted to sell the Family Products division to [[Johnson and Johnson]] but the deal fell through. In 1988 Playtex split into two companies, Playtex Apparel and Playtex Family Products, in a series of financial transactions totaling $1.3 billion.{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=i-dVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=r-EDAAAAIBAJ&pg=948,3503075&dq=joel+smilow+playtex&hl=en|date=September 16, 1988|title=Playtex to split into two companies|accessdate=December 10, 2012}} The transactions allowed Smilow to buy out other Playtex shareholders and put ownership of the brand into two separate investment groups that were owned by Smilow and other Playtex executives.{{cite news|last=Cole|first=Robert J.|title=COMPANY NEWS; Playtex Sets Buyout Pact Of $1.3 Billion|work=The New York Times|page=4|date=15 September 1988|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1988/09/15/business/company-news-playtex-sets-buyout-pact-of-1.3-billion.html}} In 1990 Playtex Products acquired [[cosmetics]] brand [[Maybelline]] for $300 million.{{cite news|title=Playtex's Smilow snares Maybelline|date=April 9, 1990|newspaper=Advertising Age|coauthors=Pat Sloan, Alan Solomon and Laurie Freeman|accessdate=December 8, 2012}}(${{formatprice|{{inflation|US|3000000000|1990|r=-3}}}} in modern dollars{{Inflation-fn|US}}). The next year Smilow sold Playtex Apparel to the [[Sara Lee Corporation]], transferring the [[Bali]], [[Hanes]], and Cross Your Heart brands for $571 million, (${{formatprice|{{inflation|US|571000000|1991|r=-3}}}} in modern dollars{{Inflation-fn|US}}) but keeping the Playtex Family Products Corporation.{{cite news|title=Sara Lee To Don Playtex Garb For $571 Million|date=August 9, 1991|first=Charles|last=Storch|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1991-08-09/business/9103270112_1_playtex-apparel-international-playtex-sara-lee|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=December 8, 2012}} In November of that year, Sara Lee also bought a 25 percent stake in Playtex Family Products for $62.5 million.{{cite news|last=News|first=Bloomberg Business|title=COMPANY NEWS; Sara Lee's Stake In Playtex Family|work=The New York Times|page=4|date=6 November 1991|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/06/business/company-news-sara-lee-s-stake-in-playtex-family.html}}(${{formatprice|{{inflation|US|62500000|1991|r=-3}}}} in modern dollars{{Inflation-fn|US}}). Playtex Products Inc. went public in 1994.{{cite news|title=Company News; Playtex Offering is most active stock on big board|work=The New York Times|page=3|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/28/business/company-news-playtex-offering-is-most-active-stock-on-big-board.html}} In 1995, another 40 percent of Playtex Products Inc. was sold to Haas Wheat & Harrison Investment Partners for $180 million{{cite news|title=Playtex Products to Sell Haas Wheat 40% Stake for $180 Million|work=The New York Times|page=4|date=March 21, 1995|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/21/business/playtex-products-to-sell-haas-wheat-40-stake-for-180-million.html}}(${{formatprice|{{inflation|US|180000000|1995|r=-3}}}} in modern dollars{{Inflation-fn|US}}). ===Recent history=== Playtex Products continued to erode Tampax's' [[market share]] throughout the late 20th century. The two companies had divided the market almost evenly by the late 1990s.{{cite book|last=Ries|first=Al|title=Focus: The Future of Your Company Depends on It|year=2005|publisher=[[HarperCollins]]|isbn=9780060799908|page=223|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=LkB21Vc30XUC&pg=PA223|accessdate=May 1, 2013}} Both makers increased profits primarily by reducing the tampon count per box, and prepared to enter [[emerging markets]], particularly in Asia, where many women still used homemade pads. In 1997 [[Procter & Gamble]] (P&G), makers of [[Always (brand)|Always]] [[sanitary napkins]] and [[pantiliner]]s, bought Tambrands for $1.25 billion, its largest acquisition up to that point, returning to the tampon sector almost two decades after pulling [[Rely (brand)|Rely]] from the market over Toxic Shock Syndrome concerns.{{cite book|last=Houppert|first=Karen|title=The Curse: Confronting the Last Unmentionable Taboo: Menstruation|year=2000|publisher=MacMillan|isbn=9781466813960|pages=39–43|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=6IlCwf5BgJ0C&pg=PA39}} Due to its strong advantage among younger women, and [[baby boomer]]s reaching [[menopause]], Playtex continued to gain market share on Tampax. After extensive [[market research]], Tampax reversed that trend with the 2002 introduction of Pearl, with an applicator designed to be as visually appealing as it was functional, and making the brand once again appealing to teens.{{cite book|title=The Game Changer: How Every Leader Can Drive Everyday Innovation|publisher=Profile Books|isbn=9781847651365|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=auCt2-LPnLkC&pg=PA1975|author=Lafley, A.G.|coauthors=Sharan, Ram|accessdate=May 1, 2013}} Playtex responded by [[litigation|litigating]]. In one suit, it alleged [[patent infringement]] over Pearl's applicator design.Defendant's motion for [[summary judgement]] granted, ''[http://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=6484296561260996706 Playtex Products Inc. v. Procter & Gamble]'', 290 F.Supp.2d 886 ([[United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio|S.D. Ohio]], 2003); vac'd and aff'd in part ''[http://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=10750678110340646559 Playtex Products Inc. v. Procter & Gamble]'', 400 F.3d 901 ([[United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit|Fed.Cir.]], 2005) It also [[alleged]] that advertising claiming Tampax Pearl had better leakage protection and comfort than Gentle Glide was [[false advertising|false]]. Playtex won a verdict prohibiting Tampax from making claims of superiority, until the decision was reversed in 2007, when Tampax made improvements in materials and manufacturing. In 2006, Sara Lee spun off its clothing sector into [[HanesBrands Inc.]], which now runs the Playtex apparel business.{{cite news|title=Sara Lee proceeds with apparel unit spinoff|publisher=The Associated Press|date=May 24, 2006|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/business/article/Sara-Lee-proceeds-with-apparel-unit-spinoff-1204371.php#ixzz2ElYKfnVH|accessdate=December 11, 2012}} The next year Playtex Products acquired the [[Hawaiian Tropic]] sunscreen company for $83 million.{{cite news|title=Playtex buys Hawaiian Tropic for about $83 million|date=April 19, 2007|publisher=Reuters|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2007/04/19/playtex-acquisition-idUSWEN667420070419|accessdate=December 11, 2012}} Later that year Playtex Products was acquired by [[Energizer Holdings]] for $1.16 billion.{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=conewsstory&refer=conews&tkr=FNSR:US&sid=aMMEZ1eS9IjA|publisher=Bloomberg|title=3M, Houghton Mifflin, Playtex: Intellectual Property (Update1)|first=Victoria|last=Slind-Flor|date=April 21, 2008|accessdate=December 11, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/economy/2007-07-13-1078973501_x.htm|newspaper=USA Today|first=Jim|last=Salter|date=July 13, 2007|accessdate=December 11, 2012|title=Energizer to acquire Playtex for $1.16B}} Playtex Products was sued in 2008, when a mother accused the company of not adequately disclosing their baby bottles contained [[bisphenol A]].{{cite news|publisher=Associated Press|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/2008-05-28-baby-bottle-lawsuit_N.htm|title=Mom files lawsuit against baby bottle maker|date=May 28, 2008|accessdate=December 11, 2012}} After Canada considered banning the chemical, the company took it out of their bottles the following year.{{cite news|newspaper=Connecticut Post|title=Playtex to drop baby bottle chemical|first=Rob|last=Varnon|date=April 21, 2008|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=CTPB&p_theme=ctpb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=120371DE92646790&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|accessdate=December 15, 2012}} ==Organization== The Playtex [[trademark]] is owned by Playtex Marketing Corp. and licensed to companies that sell products under the brand name. The Playtex bra brand is operated by HBI Branded Apparel Enterprise, LLC, a subsidiary of [[Energizer Holdings]],{{citation|url=http://www.playtex.com/|title=Playtex website|quote=HBI Branded Apparel Enterprises, LLC is a wholly owned subsidiary of Hanesbrands|accessdate=December 15, 2012|publisher=Playtex Apparel}} except in the [[European Union]] and South Africa, where Sara Lee operates the Playtex apparel brand.[http://phx.corporate-ir.net/External.File?item=UGFyZW50SUQ9MTM0NTQ3fENoaWxkSUQ9LTF8VHlwZT0z&t=1 HBI 2011 Annual Report] Playtex Products sells Playtex brand pacifiers, feminine products and other consumer goods.{{cite book|author=Beth Rubin|title=Delaware Curiosities: Quirky Characters, Roadside Oddities & Other Offbeat Stuff|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=OXh3vp6wod0C&pg=PA53|accessdate=15 December 2012|date=1 June 2007|publisher=Globe Pequot|isbn=978-0-7627-4335-3|pages=53–}}{{cite news|last=Heffernan|first=Virginia|title=THE MEDIUM; Trust Busting|work=The New York Times|page=14|date=28 March 2010|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/28/magazine/28FOB-medium-t.html}} The Playtex consumer products company is operated as Playtex Products, LLC.{{citation|url=http://www.playtexproductsinc.com/|title=Playtex Products homepage|accessdate=December 15, 2012|publisher=Playtex Products}} ==Products== [[File:Playtex Tampon package.jpg|thumb|right|A Playtex tampon package]] As of 2011, Playtex is the second-largest producer of tampons in the US.[http://phx.corporate-ir.net/External.File?item=UGFyZW50SUQ9NDUwMzEwfENoaWxkSUQ9NDc1MDQ4fFR5cGU9MQ==&t=1 Energizer Holdings 2011 Annual Report] Its best-selling tampon is the Gentle Glide brand, which was introduced in 1973.{{cite book|author=Peril|title=Pink think: becoming a woman in many uneasy lessons|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=uB68a7pXe6MC&pg=PA217|accessdate=28 April 2013|year=2002|publisher=W W Norton & Company Incorporated|isbn=978-0-393-32354-2|pages=217–}} It also manufactures the Playtex Sport tampon, which targets young athletes.{{cite news|first=Seth|last=Stevenson|accessdate=April 28, 2013|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/business/ad_report_card/2007/01/can_tampons_be_cool.html|date=January 15, 2007|title=Can Tampons be Cool|newspaper=Slate}} Both brands are sold in regular, super and super-plus absorbency.''[http://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=13464229396865168957 Playtex Products, Inc. v. Procter & Gamble]'', 635 F.Supp.2d 313 ([[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York|S.D.N.Y]], 2009). Retrieved April 30, 2013. Playtex had a 29 percent share of a $550 million market for [[tampon]]s in 1994{{cite journal |title=Playtex intros multi's, restages ultimates |author= Pam Weisz |journal=Brandweek, 10644318, |date=June 6, 1994 |volume=35 |issue=23}} and a 30 percent share of a $780 market by 2000.Kelly, E 2000, 'Hardly 'Play'-ed Out: Playtex Rebounds', Fortune, 141, 6, pp. 44-45, Business Source Complete, EBSCOhost, viewed 17 December 2012. Historically baby products were a small portion of Playtex Products' revenues, but by 2000 they made up 38 percent of the company's revenues. As of that year it had a 60 percent share of the market for "sippy cups" and an 84 percent share of the market for disposable baby-bottle liners. Other baby products include Chubs Baby Wipes, [[Baby Magic]] toiletries (until 2007), and [[Diaper Genie]]. It also produces Banana Board sunscreen, Playtex gloves, and Wet Ones wipes.{{cite news|last=News|first=Bloomberg|title=Energizer Holdings Agrees to Buy Playtex Products for $1.2 Billion|work=The New York Times|page=7|date=13 July 2007|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/13/business/13energizer.html}} Playtex Products also manufactures the Banana Boat and Hawaiian Tropic sunscreen brands, household gloves, diaper pails, cleansing cloths and the Ortho-Pro and Binky pacifiers. Playtex Apparel sells bras, panties and shapewear. According to Energizer Holdings, which owns the Playtex Apparel brand, their products include "solutions for hard to fit figures." The brand has the strongest loyalty among customers who prioritize fit. As of 2002, it was the second largest producer of bras.{{citation|title=Victoria's Secret|publisher=Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth|year=2002|accessdate=December 10, 2012|url=http://digitalstrategies.tuck.dartmouth.edu/cds-uploads/case-studies/pdf/6-0014.pdf}} Its more popular bras include the Living Bra, the Cross Your Heart bra, and the Eighteen Hour Bra. The company has been producing and marketing the Cross Your Heart bra since 1954 under the slogan that it "lifts and separates," now a well-known phrase in popular culture. The Eighteen Hour bra has been marketed on the premise of comfort since the 1970s.{{cite book|author1=Jane Farrell Beck|author2=Colleen Gau|title=Uplift: The Bra in America|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=MtRbdACUkqgC&pg=PA167|accessdate=17 December 2012|date=22 October 2002|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|isbn=978-0-8122-1835-0|pages=167–}} [[File:Playtex baby bottles.png|thumb|right|Playtex baby bottles]] {{columns-list|2| '''Playtex Apparel''' *Cross Your Heart *Eighteen-hour bra *Playtex Secrets *Full support *Everyday basics *Panties *Shapewear '''Playtex Products''' *Gloves *Baby products *Feminine care }} {{-}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == {{commons category}} *[http://www.playtex.com/ Playtex official site] *[http://www.playtexfits.com/ Playtex fits] – bra campaign site *[http://www.hanesbrands.com HanesBrands Inc.] {{energizer}} {{HanesBrands}} {{lingerie}} [[Category:Feminine hygiene brands]] [[Category:Lingerie brands]] [[Category:Companies established in 1932]] [[Category:Companies based in Westport, Connecticut]]

[[Gibson Les Paul]] }} '''Hillel Slovak''' (April 13, 1962–June 25, 1988) was an Israeli-American musician best known as the original guitarist and founding member of the [[Los Angeles]] rock band [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]]. Prior to his death of a heroin overdose in 1988, Slovak recorded two albums with the band, ''[[Freaky Styley]]'' (1985) and ''[[The Uplift Mofo Party Plan]]'' (1987). ==Biography== ===Early years=== Slovak was born in [[Haifa]], [[Israel]] to [[Jewish People|Jewish]] parents who were survivors of the [[Holocaust]]. His mother was of [[History of the Jews in Poland|Polish]] descent and his father of [[Yugoslavia]]n descent. The family emigrated to the [[United States|U.S.]] when Hillel was four. They settled in [[Queens]], [[New York]], then in 1967 relocated to [[Southern California]]. Slovak attended Bancroft Jr. High School in [[Hollywood]], where he met future bandmates [[Jack Irons]] and [[Flea (musician)|Michael "Flea" Balzary]]. The three then attended [[Fairfax High School (Los Angeles)|Fairfax High School]]. While at Fairfax, Slovak learned how to play guitar. He, Irons, and Balzary, whom he introduced to rock music, met future bandmate [[Anthony Kiedis]]. Slovak formed a band with Irons on drums and two other high school friends, [[Alain Johannes]] and Todd Strasman. They called their band [[Chain Reaction (band)|Chain Reaction]], then changed the name to [[What Is This?|Anthym]] after their first gig. Slovak became dissatisfied with Strasman's bass playing and eventually taught Balzary to play bass. Balzary quickly took over bass duties in Anthym. After graduating from high school, the band changed their name to [[What Is This?]]. Balzary left Anthym around this time to accept an offer of playing bass in the prominent L.A. punk band [[Fear (band)|Fear]]. What Is This? continued on and performed many shows along the [[California]] coast. ===Red Hot Chili Peppers=== One night, Kiedis' friend Gary Allen suggested that Kiedis, Slovak, and Balzary form a "one-off" band and open for his own band. For the gig, they enlisted Irons as their drummer and wrote the song "Out in LA". They dubbed themselves "Tony Flow and the Miraculously Majestic Masters of Mayhem". They were a hit with the club audience and the owner asked them to come back the next week. [[Image:EarlyRHCP.jpg|220px|thumb|left|Red Hot Chili Peppers in 1988 during the ''Uplift Mofo Party Plan'' tour; (left to right) [[Jack Irons]], [[Flea (musician)|Flea]], [[Anthony Kiedis]], Hillel Slovak]] The band changed their name to [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]], and Kiedis began writing more lyrics. The lyrics would eventually become songs such as "Green Heaven" and "[[True Men Don't Kill Coyotes]]". Over the course of the next six months, the Red Hot Chili Peppers played many shows in L.A. clubs and became something of an underground hit. They scored a record deal with [[EMI]] only six months after the band was formed, and were set to record their first album. Balzary left Fear to pursue the Red Hot Chili Peppers. Unfortunately, What Is This? had also gotten a record deal. Since Slovak considered the Chili Peppers to merely be a side project and not a serious commitment, he left them to concentrate on What Is This? During the recording of the second What Is This? album, Slovak became frustrated with the band. He contacted Balzary about rejoining the Red Hot Chili Peppers. This came at an opportune time, as Kiedis and Balzary were both dissatisfied with Slovak's replacement, [[Jack Sherman (guitarist)|Jack Sherman]]. After the culmination of the promotional tour for their first album, Sherman was fired and Slovak rejoined the band. Slovak returned to the Chili Peppers for their second and third albums, ''[[Freaky Styley]]'' and ''[[The Uplift Mofo Party Plan]]''. The songs "Skinny Sweaty Man", "Me and My Friends", "No Chump Love Sucker" and probably "Savior" from the latter album were written about Slovak. He was nicknamed "Slim Bob Billy", "Slim", or "Huckleberry", and throughout the albums Kiedis calls him by these nicknames before he starts a guitar solo. Slovak was mentioned many times in Kiedis' autobiography 'Scar Tissue'. Mr Kiedis talks fondly of his memories of his good friend. ===Death=== Slovak and Kiedis became addicted to [[heroin]] early in their careers. Deciding to give sobriety a chance, both Kiedis and Hillel stopped using prior to their European tour in support of ''The Uplift Mofo Party Plan''. During the tour both Kiedis and Hillel experienced intense heroin withdrawal - Hillel seemingly much more unstable than Kiedis - and upon returning home they both resumed their addictions. Little is known about his life the weeks following the tour, aside from a phone call to his brother. Slovak was found dead due to a [[Speedball (drug)]] overdose on [[June 25]], [[1988]], shortly after the band returned from the European tour. He is interred at [[Mount Sinai Memorial Park Cemetery]] in [[Hollywood Hills]], [[California]]. His last recording, a cover version of the [[Jimi Hendrix]] song "[[Fire (Hendrix song)|Fire]]", would later appear in the ''[[Abbey Road EP]]'' and album ''[[Mothers Milk]]''. ==Legacy== Slovak's work was one of the major contributing factors to the Red Hot Chili Peppers' early sound. He was also a huge influence on a young [[John Frusciante]], who would later replace him as guitarist in the band. Frusciante based a lot of his playing style on Slovak's work. The songs "[[Knock Me Down]]" (from ''[[Mother's Milk]]'') and "My Lovely Man" (from ''[[Blood Sugar Sex Magik]]'') were written as tributes to Hillel. In 1999, a book titled "Behind the Sun: The Diary & Art of Hillel Slovak" was published. The book was authored by Slovak's brother James Slovak and features writings from his brother's diaries, paintings, photos and hand written notes from Kiedis and Balzary. ==Discography== With '''What Is This?''' *''[[Squeezed (what is this?)|Squeezed]]'' – (1984) *''[[What Is This? (album)|What Is This?]]'' – (1985) *''[[3 Out of 5 Live]]'' – (1985) With '''Red Hot Chili Peppers''' *''[[Freaky Styley]]'' – (1985) *''[[The Uplift Mofo Party Plan]]'' – (1987) *''[[The Abbey Road E.P.]]'' – (1988) **Performs on only one track, "[[Fire (Hendrix song)|Fire]]" *''[[What Hits!?]]'' – (1992) *''[[Out in L.A.]]'' – (1994) *''[[Under the Covers: Essential Red Hot Chili Peppers]]'' – (1998) *''[[The Best of the Red Hot Chili Peppers]]'' – (1998) ==References== * {{cite book | last = Kiedis | first = Anthony | authorlink = Anthony Kiedis | coauthors = Slovak, James | title = [[Scar Tissue (book)|Scar Tissue]] | publisher = [[Hyperion (publisher)|Hyperion]] | date= [[October 6]], [[2004]] | location = | pages = | url = http://www.amazon.com/dp/1401301010/ | doi = | isbn = 1-4013-0101-0 }} ==External links== *[http://www.crushgroove.com/ Official site for "Behind the Sun", a publication of Hillel's diaries] *{{findagrave|6446}} {{Red Hot Chili Peppers}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Slovak, Hillel}} [[Category:Deaths by heroin overdose in California]] [[Category:American rock guitarists]] [[Category:American funk guitarists]] [[Category:Lead guitarists]] [[Category:Israeli-Americans]] [[Category:Jewish American musicians]] [[Category:Naturalized citizens of the United States]] [[Category:What Is This? members]] [[Category:Red Hot Chili Peppers members]] [[Category:Israeli musicians]] [[Category:Fairfax High School (Los Angeles) alumni]] [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:1988 deaths]] [[bg:Хилел Словак]] [[cs:Hillel Slovak]] [[da:Hillel Slovak]] [[de:Hillel Slovak]] [[es:Hillel Slovak]] [[fr:Hillel Slovak]] [[id:Hillel Slovak]] [[it:Hillel Slovak]] [[he:הלל סלובק]] [[lt:Hilelis Slovakas]] [[hu:Hillel Slovak]] [[nl:Hillel Slovak]] [[ja:ヒレル・スロヴァク]] [[no:Hillel Slovak]] [[pl:Hillel Slovak]] [[pt:Hillel Slovak]] [[ru:Словак, Хиллел]] [[simple:Hillel Slovak]] [[sl:Hillel Slovak]] [[fi:Hillel Slovak]] [[sv:Hillel Slovak]] [[tr:Hillel Slovak]]
