The '''Central American Squirrel Monkey''' (''Saimiri oerstedii'') is a [[squirrel monkey]] [[species]] from [[Central America]]. It is found in [[Costa Rica]] and [[Panama]] on the [[Pacific]] coast. Even within Costa Rica and Panama the Central American Squirrel Monkey's range is highly restricted.  Within Panama its range is limited to the Western Pacific tip near the Costa Rica border, and within Costa Rica its range is limited to the Central and Southern Pacific coast, primarily in [[Manuel Antonio National Park|Maunuel Antonio]] and [[Corcovado National Park|Corcovado]] [[National Parks]].  

It is a small monkey with an orange back and a distinctive white and black facial mask.  It lives in large groups that typically contain between 20 and 75 monkeys.  It has one of the most egalitarian social structures of all monkeys.  Females do not form dominance hierarchies, and males only form dominance hierachies at breeding season.  But even during breeding season, males do not fight over females and do not attempt to force females to copulate with them.  It has an omnivorous diet, eating fruits, other plant materials, [[invertebrate]]s (especially [[grasshopper]]s and [[caterpillar]]s) and some small [[vertebrate]]s.  It turn, it has a number of predators, including [[bird of prey|raptors]], [[Felidae|cats]] and smakes.

Reproduction is seasonal, with all births occurring within a short period of time in February and March.  Females become sexually mature at 2 1/2 years, and males become sexually mature at 4 to 5 years.  Sexually mature females leave the natal group, but males can remain with their natal group their entire life.  The Central American Squirrel Monkey can live for more than 15 years.

==Description==

The Central American Squirrel Monkey differs in coloration from squirrel monkeys from [[South America]]. While South American squirrel monkeys tend to be primarily greenish in color, the Central American Squirrel Monkey has a orange back with olive shoulders, hips and tail and white undersides. The hands and feet are also orange.  There is a black cap at the top of the head, and a black tip at the end of the tail.  Males generally have lighter caps than females.  The face is white with black rims around the eyes and black around the nose and mouth.<ref name=pic>{{cite book|title=The Pictorial Guide to the Living Primates|author=Rowe, N.|page=98|year=1996|isbn=0-9648825-0-7}}</ref><ref name=field>{{cite book|title=Neotropical Rainforest Mammals A Field Guide|edition=Second Edition|author=Emmons, L.|page=126–127|year=1997|isbn=0-226-20721-8}}</ref>
[[Image:Central American Squirrel Monkey 2.jpeg|thumb|left|Full body coloration]]

There are two subspecies which are similar in coloration, but differ in the shade of the cap.  The northern subspecies, living in Central Pacific Costa Rica, has a lighter cap than the southern subspecies, which lives in Panama and in parts of Costa Rica near Panama.<ref name=field/>

Adults reach a length of between {{convert|266|and|291|mm|in|lk=on}}, excluding tail, and a weight between {{convert|600|and|950|g|oz|lk=on}}.<ref name=field/><ref name=perspective>{{cite book|title=Primates in Perspective|chapter=The Cebines|author=Jack, K.|editor = Campbell, C., Fuentes, A., MacKinnon, K., Panger, M., & Bearder, S.|year=2007|page=107–120|isbn=978-0-19-517133-4}}</ref>  The tail is longer than the body, and between {{convert|362|and|389|mm|in|lk=on|abbr=on}} in length.<ref name=field/>  As with other squirrel monkeys, there is considerable [[sexual dimorphism]].  On average, males weigh 16% more than females.<ref name=perspective/>  Males have an average body weight of {{convert|829|g|oz|lk=on|abbr=on}} and females have an average body weight of {{convert|695|g|oz|lk=on|abbr=on}}.<ref name=perspective/>

Squirrel monkeys have the largest brains of all [[primates]] relative to their body size.<ref>{{cite web|title=Squirrel Monkey|publisher=Rainforest Alliance|url=http://www.rainforest-alliance.org/resources/forest-facts/species-profiles/squirrelmonkey.html|accessdate=2008-10-18}}</ref>  The Central American Squirrel Monkey's brain weighs about {{convert|25.7|g|oz|lk=on|abbr=on}}, or about 4% of its body weight.<ref name=pic/>

Unlike larger relatives, such as the [[capuchin monkey|capuchin]], [[spider monkey|spider]] and [[howler monkey]]s, adult Central American Squirrel Monkeys do not have a fully prehensile tail.  The tail has some flexibility, allowing it to help the monkey cling to a tree.  Newborn infant Central American Squirrel Monkeys do have fully prehensile tails, but lose that feature within a few weeks after birth.

==Distribution and habitat==

The Central American Squirrel Monkey has a restricted distribution in [[Costa Rica]] and [[Panama]].  It lives only near the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] coast.  Its range covers Central Pacific Costa Rica in the north through western Panama.

The Central American Squirrel Monkey lives lowland forests.<ref name=pic/>  It is restricted to [[secondary forest]]s and also in [[primary forest]]s which have been partially [[logging|logged]].<ref name=costa>{{cite book|title=The Natural History of Costa Rican Mammals|author=Wainwright, M.|year=2002|page=131–134|isbn=0-9705678-1-2}}</ref>  It requires forests with abundant low and mid-level vegetation.<ref name=field/><ref name=costa/>  It has difficulty surviving in tall, mature, undisturbed forests that do not have abundant low level vegetation.<ref name=field/>

The Central American Squirrel Monkey lives in two of Costa Rica's national parks — [[Manuel Antonio National Park]] and [[Corcovado National Park]] — where it can be seen by visitors.<ref name=watching>{{cite book|author = Hunter, L., Andrew, D.|title = ''Watching Wildlife Central America''|year = 2002|pages = 148|isbn=1-86450-034-4}}</ref>  However, it is not as commonly seen in these parks as the [[White-headed Capuchin]] or the [[Mantled Howler]] monkeys.<ref>{{cite book|author = Hunter, L., Andrew, D.|title = ''Watching Wildlife Central America''|year = 2002|pages = 100|isbn=1-86450-034-4}}</ref>

==Behavior==

===Social Structure===

Central American Squirrel Monkeys live in groups containing several adult males, several adult females and juveniles.  The group size tends to be smaller than that of South American squirrel monkeys, but still larger than many other New World Monkey species.  Group size generally numbers between 20 and 75 monkeys, with a mean group size of 41 monkeys.<ref name=costa/><ref name=perspective/>  Groups in excess of 100 sometimes occur, but these are generally believed to be temporary mergers of two groups.<ref name=iucn/>  On average, groups contain about 60% more females than males.<ref name=perspective/>  

The squirrel monkey groups have a home range of between 35 and 63 hectares.<ref name=costa/>  Group ranges can overlap, especially in large, protected areas such as [[Manuel Antonio National Park]].  Less overlap occurs in more fragmented areas.<ref name=costa/>  Groups can cover 2500 to 4200 meters per day.<ref name=sussman>{{cite book|title=Primate Ecology and Social Structure Volume 2: New World Monkeys|edition=Revised First Edition|author=Sussman, R.|year=2003|page=86|isbn=0-536-74364-9}}</ref>  Unlike, some other monkey species, the group does not split into separate foraging groups during the day.  But individual monkeys may separate for the main group to engage in different activities (e.g., foraging, playing, resting) for periods of time, and thus the group may be deispersed over an area of up to three acres at any given time.<ref name=boinski>{{cite book|title=The Primate Anthology|chapter=Monkeys with Inflated Sex Appeal|author=Boinski, S.|editor=Ciochon, R. & Nisbett, R.|page=174–179|year=1992|isbn=0-13-613845-4}}</ref>   The group tends to sleep in the same trees every night for months at a time, unlike other squirrel monkeys.<ref name=boinski/>

There are no dominance hierarchies among the females, and the females do not form coalitions.<ref name=iucn/><ref name=perspective/>  Males only form dominance hierarchies during breeding season.<ref name=perspective/>  Males in the group are generally related to each other and thus tend to form strong affiliations.<ref name=perspective/>  This is especially the case among males of the same age.<ref name=costa/>  Neither males nor females are dominant over each other.  The Central American Squirrel Monkey's egalitarian social system is unique to Central American squirrel monkeys.  In South American species, either the females (''S. boliviensis'') or males (''S. sciureus'') are dominant over the other sex, and both sexes form stable dominance hierarchies.<ref name=perspective/>  Groups generally do not compete or fight with each other.<ref name=iucn/>  Males are primarily responsible for watching for predators.<ref name=iucn/>

Although South American species of squirrel monkeys often travel with and feed together with [[capuchin monkey]]s, the Central American Squirrel Monkey only rarely associates with the [[White-headed Capuchin]].  This appears to be related to the fact that the distribution food that the Central American Squirrel Monkey eats, differs from that of the South American squirrel monkeys.  As a result of the different food distribution, associating with capuchin monkeys would impose higher foraging costs for the Central American Squirrel Monkey than for their South American counterparts.  In addition, while male [[White-headed Capuchin]]s are alert to predators, they devote more attention to detecting rival males than to detecting predators.  Therefore, associating with capuchins would provide less predator detection benefits and impose higher foraging costs on the Central American Squirrel Monkey than on South American squirrel monkeys.<ref name=perspective>{{cite book|title=Primates in Perspective|chapter=The Cebines|author=Jack, K.|editor = Campbell, C., Fuentes, A., MacKinnon, K., Panger, M., & Bearder, S.|year=2007|page=107–120|isbn=978-0-19-517133-4}}</ref><ref name=move>{{cite book|title=On the Move|chapter=Social Manipulation Within and Between Troops Mediates Primate Group Movement|author=Boinski, S.|editor=Boinski, S. and Garber, P.|page=447–448|year=2000|isbn=0-226-06340-2}}</ref>

Certain bird species associate with the Central American Squirrel Monkey.  The birds follow the monkeys in a attempt to prey on insects and small vertebrates that the monkeys flush out.  At [[Corcovado National Park]], bird species known to regularly follow squirrel monkeys include the [[Double-toothed Kite]], the [[Grey-headed Tanager]] and the [[Tawny-winged Woodcreeper]], but other species, such as other [[woodcreeper]]s, [[motmot]]s, [[trogon]]s, and even some birds of prey do so as well.  This activity increases during the wet season, when [[arthropod]]s are harder to find.<ref name=costa/>

===Diet===
[[Image:Central American Squirrel Monkey 3.jpeg|thumb|right|Central American Squirrel Monkey foraging in [[Manuel Antonio National Park]] in [[Costa Rica]]]]

The Central American Squirrel Monkey is [[omnivore|omnivorous]].  Its diet includes insects and insect larvae (especially [[grasshopper]]s and [[caterpillar]]s), spiders, fruit, leaves, bark, flowers and nectar.  It also eats small [[vertebrate]]s, including bats, birds, lizards and frogs.  It finds its food foraging through the lower and middle levels of the forest, typically between fifteen and thirty feet high.<ref name=costa/><ref name=boinski/>

It has a unique method of capturing [[Tent-making Bat]]s.  It looks for roosting bats by looking for their tents (which are made of a folded leaf).  When it finds a bat it climbs to a higher level and jumps onto the tent from above, attempting to dislodge the bat.  If the fallen bat doesn't fly away in time, the monkey pounces on it on the ground and eats it.<ref name=costa/> 

It eats a wide variety of fruits.  Fruits eaten include [[cecropia]]s, [[legume]]s, [[fig]]s, [[palm tree|palms]], [[Symphonia globulifera|cerillo]], [[Pseudolmedia|quiubra]], [[Xylopia|yayo flaco]], wild [[cashew]] fruits, and fruits from relatives of the [[black pepper]] and [[coffee]] plants.<ref name=costa/><ref name=boinski/>

The Central American Squirrel Monkey is believed to be an important seed disperser.  It is also believed to be a pollenator of certain flowers, including the [[passion flower]].  While it is not a significant agricultural pest, it does sometimes eat corn, coffee, [[banana]]s and [[mango]]s.

Two thirds to three quarters of each day is spent foraging for food.  It has difficulty finding its desired food late in the wet season, when fewer [[arthropods]] are available to eat.<ref name=field/>

===Communication===

The Central American Squirrel Monkey is noisy.  It makes many squeals, whistles and chirps.<ref name=field/>  It also travels through the forest noisily, disturbing vegetation as it moves through.<ref name=field/>  Its has four main calls, which have been described as a "smooth chuck", a "bent mask chuck", a "peep" and a "twitter".<ref name=pic/>

===Predators===

Predators of the Central American Squirrel Monkey include [[bird of prey|raptor]]s, [[Felidae|cats]] and snakes.  Both constricting and venomous snakes prey on squirrel monkeys.  Raptors are particularly effective predators of Central American Squirrel Monkeys.<ref name=perspective/>  The oldest males bear most of the responsibility for detecting predators.<ref name=costa/>  When a Central American Squirrel Monkey detects a raptor, it gives a high-pitched alarm peep and dives for cover.  All other squirrel monkeys that hear the alarm call also dive for cover.  The monkeys are particularly cautious about raptors, and give alarms and dive for cover when they detect any raptor-like object, including small [[airplane]]s and even falling branches and large leaves.<ref name=boinski/>

Predator detection by the males becomes particularly important during the period when the infants are born.  Raptors spend significantly more time near the squirrel monkey troops during this period, and prey on a significant number of the newborn infants.  Other animals that prey on Central American Squirrel Monkey infants include [[toucan]]s, [[tayra]]s, [[opossum]]s, [[coati]]s, snakes, and even [[spider monkey]]s.<ref name=boinski/>

==Reproduction==
[[Image:Central American Squirrel Monkey baby gets a ride.jpeg|thumb|left|Two month old infant riding on mother's back]]

The breeding season for the Central American Squirrel Monkey is in September.<ref name=costa/>  All females come into [[Estrous cycle|estrus]] at virtually the same time.  A month or two before the breeding season begins, males become larger.  This is not due to extra muscle, but due to altered water balance within the male's body.  This, in turn, is caused by the male hormone [[testosterone]] being converted to [[estrogen]].  The more testosterone a male produces, the more he grows in advance of the breeding season.  Since males within a group have not been observed fighting over access to females during breeding season, nor attempting to force females to copulate with them, it is believed that female choice determines which males get to breed with females.  And females tend to prefer the males that expand the most in advance of breeding season.  This may be because the most enlarged males are generally the oldest and the most effective at detecting predators.  Or this may be a case of runaway [[sexual selection|intersexual selection]].<ref name=boinski/>

Males sometimes leave their group for short periods of time during the breeding season in order to try to mate with females from neighboring groups.  Females are receptive to males from other groups, although resident males attempt to repel the intruding males.  The [[gestation period]] is six months, and the infants are born within the span of a single week during February and March.  A single infant is typically born.<ref name=costa/><ref name=perspective/><ref name=boinski/>

The infant remains dependent on its mother for about one year.<ref name=costa/>  Females give birth every 12 months, so the prior infant becomes independent at about the same time the new infant is born.  Females become sexually mature at 2 1/2 years old, while males become sexually mature at between 4 and 5 years old.<ref name=perspective/>  The females leave their natal group upon reaching sexual maturity, while males usually remain with their natal group their entire lives.  This is different from South American squirrel monkey species, where either males disperse from their natal group or both sexes disperse.<ref name=perspective/>  Males of the same age tend to associate with each other in age cohorts.  If upon reaching sexual maturity, an age cohort may choose to leave the group and attempt to oust the males from another group in order to attain increased reproductive opportunities.<ref name=perspective/>

The lifespan of the Central American Squirrel Monkey in the wild is unknown, but captive specimens have been know to live more than 15 years.<ref name=costa/>  Other squirrel monkey species are known to be able to live more than 20 years.<ref name=perspective/>

==Status==
It was once believed that the Central American Squirrel Monkey was just a population of a South American species of squirrel monkey brought to Central America by humans. Evidence for this theory included the very small range of the Central American Squirrel Monkey and the large gap from the range of any other squirrel monkey species. However, a study of [[nuclear DNA|nuclear]] and [[mitochondrial DNA]] demonstrated that the Central American Squirrel Monkey is indeed a separate species that apparently diverged from the South American species long ago - at least 260,000 years ago and possibly more than 4 million years ago.<ref name=perspectives>{{cite book | author = Rylands, A.; Groves, C.; Mittenmeier, R.; Cortes-Ortiz, L.; Hines, J.| editor = Estrada, A.; Garber, P.A.; Pavelka, M.S.M.; Luecke, L. | chapter = Taxonomy and Distributions of Mesoamerican Primates | title = New Perspectives in the Study of Mesoamerican Primates| pages = p. 38| id = ISBN 978-0-387-25854-6 | year = 2006}}</ref>

[[Image:Central American Squirrel Monkey 7.jpeg|thumb|left|Wild Central American Squirrel Monkey encroaching on a balcony of a development near [[Manuel Antonio National Park]]]]
One popular theory is that squirrel monkeys did live in Columbia during the late [[Miocene]] or [[Pliocene]] and these squirrel monkeys migrated to Central America, becoming the ancestors of the current Central American species. According to this theory, the [[Guatemalan Black Howler]] migrated to Central America around the same time. However, passage through the [[isthmus]] of [[Panama]] later closed due to rising oceans, and later opened up to another wave of migration about 2 million years ago. These later migrants, ancestors to modern populations of [[White-headed Capuchin]]s, [[Mantled Howler]]s and [[Geoffroy's Spider Monkey]]s, outcompeted the earlier migrants, leading to the small range of the Central American Squirrel Monkey (as well as the Guatemalan Black Howler).<ref>{{cite book | author = Ford, S.| editor = Estrada, A.; Garber, P.A.; Pavelka, M.S.M.; Luecke, L. | chapter = The Biographic History of Mesoamerican Primates | title = New Perspectives in the Study of Mesoamerican Primates| pages = pp. 100-107| id = ISBN 978-0-387-25854-6 | year = 2006}}</ref>

It has been estimated that the population of the Central American Squirrel Monkey has been reduced from about 200,000 in the 1970s to less than 5000.<ref name=watching/>  This is believed to be largely due to [[deforestation]], [[hunting]], and capture for the [[pet]] trade.<ref name=watching/> There are significant efforts within Costa Rica to try to preserve this monkey from extinction.<ref>[http://www.theboquetetimes.com/html/squirlmonkey.html Saving the Central American Squirrel Monkey<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.ascomoti.com/index.html Save the Mono Titi Manuel Antonio Costa Rica<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> A reforestation project within Panama tries to preserve the vanishing population of the Chiriqui Province <ref>[http://www.saimiri.org/en -->]</ref>.

The population density has been estimated at 36 monkeys per kilometer in Costa Rica and 130 monkeys per kilometer in Panama.<ref name=sussman/>

As of 2008, the Central American Squirrel Monkey is listed as "vulnerable" from a conservation standpoint by the [[IUCN]].  This is due to the fact that its range encompasses just 8000 square [[kilometer]]s, its range is fragmented, and it suffers from ongoing habitat loss.  However, this assessment is an improvement from the 2003 assessment, in which the Central American Squirrel Monkey was listed as "endangered".<ref name=iucn/>

==Taxonomy==
The Central American Squirrel Monkey is a member of the family [[Cebidae]], the family of [[New World monkeys]] containing [[capuchin monkey]]s, [[squirrel monkey]]s, [[tamarin]]s and [[marmoset]]s.  Within the family Cebidae, it is a member of the subfamily [[Saimiriinae]], the subfamily containing squirrel monkeys.<ref name=groves2>{{MSW3 Groves|page=Saimiriinae|id=12100283}}</ref>  It is one of five recognized species of squirrel monkey, and the only species occurring outside South America.<ref name=perspective/>  The Central American Squirrel Monkey is placed in genus ''[[Saimiri]]'' (Voigt, 1831) along with all the other squirrel monkey species.

There are two subspecies of the Central American Squirrel Monkey:<ref name=msw3/>

* [[Black-crowned Central American Squirrel Monkey]], ''Saimiri oerstedii oerstedii''
* [[Grey-crowned Central American Squirrel Monkey]], ''Saimiri oerstedii citrinellus''

''S. o. oerstadii'' lives in the western [[Pacific]] portion of Panama and the [[Osa Peninsula]] area of Costa Rica (including [[Corcovado National Park]]), while ''S. o. citrinellus'' lives in the Central Pacific portion of Costa Rica.  It has been estimated (most recently in 2003) that the remaining wild population of ''S. o. citrinellus'' is only about 1300 to 1800 individuals.<ref name=iucn/>

{{About|the battle in 1800|the battle in 1703|First Battle of Höchstädt}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}}
{{Infobox military conflict
|conflict=Battle of Höchstädt
|coordinates       = {{coord|48|36|0|N|10|33|0|E|region:DE_type:event|display=title}}|image=
|caption=
|partof=the War of the [[Second Coalition]]
|date=19 June 1800
|place=[[Höchstädt an der Donau|Höchstädt]], and surrounding villages of [[Blindheim]], [[Dillingen an der Donau|Dillingen]], and [[Donauwörth]], in present day Germany
|result=French victory
|combatant1={{flagicon|France}} [[French First Republic|France]]
|combatant2={{flag|Holy Roman Empire}} [[Habsburg Monarchy|Austria]]
|commander1=[[Jean Victor Marie Moreau]]
|commander2=[[Pál Kray]]
|strength1=60,000
|strength2=30,000
|casualties1=approximately 2,000
|casualties2=5,000 dead, wounded and captured
|source=[[Digby Smith]], ''Battle of Höchstädt,'' <u>Napoleonic Wars Databook</u>. London: Greenhill Press, 1998, p. 178}}
{{Campaignbox Second Coalition}}

The '''Battle of Höchstädt''' was fought on 19 June 1800 on the north bank of the [[Danube]] near [[Höchstädt an der Donau|Höchstädt]], and resulted in a French victory under General [[Jean Victor Marie Moreau]] against the [[Austria]]ns under Baron [[Pál Kray]]. The Austrians were subsequently forced back into the fortress town of [[Ulm]]. Instead of attacking the heavily fortified, walled city, which would result in massive losses of personnel and time, Moreau dislodged Kray's supporting forces defending the Danube passage further east.  As a line of retreat eastward disappeared, Kray quickly abandoned Ulm, and withdrew into [[Electorate of Bavaria|Bavaria]]. This opened the Danube pathway toward [[Vienna]].

The Danube passage connecting Ulm, [[Donauworth]], [[Ingolstadt]] and [[Regensburg]] had strategic importance in the ongoing competition for European hegemony between France and the [[Holy Roman Empire]]; the army that commanded the Danube, especially its passage through [[Duchy of Württemberg|Württemberg]] and Bavaria, could command access to the important cities of [[Munich]] and the seat of Habsburg authority: Vienna.  The end result of the battle was the opposite of what had occurred on those same fields almost 100 years earlier, when the armies of the [[Grand Alliance (League of Augsburg)|Grand Alliance]] had faced the armies of France during the [[War of the Spanish Succession]]. At the Second Battle of Höchstädt in 1704, called the [[Battle of Blenheim]] by the English, the overwhelming Allied victory ensured the safety of Vienna from the Franco-Bavarian army, thus preventing the collapse of the Grand Alliance. France's loss during that engagement opened the pathway into France for the allied English and Austrian forces.

==Background==
{{main|French Revolutionary Wars}}

Although the [[First Coalition]] forces achieved several initial victories at [[Battle of Verdun (1792)|Verdun]], [[Battle of Kaiserslautern|Kaiserslautern]], [[Battle of Neerwinden (1793)|Neerwinden]], [[Battle of Mainz|Mainz]], [[Battle of Amberg|Amberg]] and [[Battle of Wurzburg|Wurzburg]], the efforts of [[Napoleon Bonaparte]] in northern [[Italian campaigns of the French Revolutionary Wars|Italy]] pushed Austrian forces back and resulted in the negotiation of the [[Peace of Leoben]] (17 April 1797) and the subsequent [[Treaty of Campo Formio]] (October 1797).<ref>Timothy Blanning, ''The French Revolutionary Wars'', New York, Oxford University Press, pp. 41–59.</ref>  This treaty proved difficult to administer. Austria was slow to give up some of the Venetian territories. A Congress convened at Rastatt for the purposes of deciding which southwestern German states would be [[German mediatization|mediatised]] to compensate the dynastic houses for territorial losses, but was unable to make any progress. Supported by French republican forces, Swiss insurgents staged several uprisings, ultimately causing the overthrow of the [[Old Swiss Confederation|Swiss Confederation]] after 18 months of civil war.<ref>Blanning, pp. 200–280.</ref> By early 1799, the [[French Directory]] had become impatient with stalling tactics employed by Austria. An uprising in Naples raised further alarms, and recent gains in Switzerland suggested the timing was fortuitous for the French to venture on another campaign in northern Italy and southwestern Germany.<ref>Blanning, p. 200.</ref>
[[File:Hohentwiel-luftbild.jpg|thumbnail||The Battles of Stockach and Engen in May 1800, followed by a larger battle at Messkirch, followed the Hohentwiel capitulation to the French]]
At the beginning of 1800, the armies of France and Austria faced each other across the Rhine.  Feldzeugmeister Pál Kray  led approximately 120,000 troops. In addition to his Austrian regulars, his force included 12,000 men from the Electorate of Bavaria, 6,000 troops from the Duchy of Württemberg, 5,000 soldiers of low quality from the [[Archbishopric of Mainz]], and 7,000 militiamen from the [[County of Tyrol]]. Of these, 25,000 men were deployed east of [[Lake Constance|Lake Constance (Bodensee)]] to protect the [[Vorarlberg]]. Kray posted his main body of 95,000 soldiers in the L-shaped angle where the Rhine changes direction from a westward flow along the northern border of Switzerland to a northward flow along the eastern border of France. Unwisely, Kray set up his main magazine at [[Stockach]], near the northwestern end of Lake Constance, only a day's march from French-held Switzerland.<ref>James R. Arnold, ''Marengo and Hohenlinden: Napoleon's Rise to Power'', Pen & Sword Military, 2005, pp.  197–199.</ref>

General of Division Jean Victor Marie Moreau commanded a modestly-equipped army of 137,000 French troops. Of these, 108,000 troops were available for field operations while the other 29,000 watched the Swiss border and held the Rhine fortresses.  Napoleon Bonaparte  offered a plan of operations based on outflanking the Austrians by a push from Switzerland, but Moreau declined to follow it. Rather, Moreau planned to cross the Rhine near [[Basel]] where the river swung to the north. A French column would distract Kray from Moreau's true intentions by crossing the Rhine from the west. Bonaparte wanted [[Claude Lecourbe]]'s corps to be detached to Italy after the initial battles, but Moreau had other plans.<ref name=Arnold199>Arnold, 199–201</ref>   Through a series of complicated maneuvers in which he flanked, double flanked, and reflanked Kray's army, Moreau's forces lay on the eastern slope of the [[Black Forest]], while portions of Kray's army was still guarding the passes on the other side.<ref>W.M. Sloane, ''Life of Napoleon.'' France, 1896, p. 109.</ref>   [[Battle of Stockach (1800)|Battles at Engen and Stockach]] were fought on 3 May 1800 between the Moreau's and Kray's armies.  The fighting near [[Engen, Germany|Engen]] resulted in a stalemate with heavy losses on both sides. However, while the two main armies were engaged at Engen, Claude Lecourbe captured Stockach from its Austrian defenders under the Joseph, Prince of Lorraine-Vaudemont. The loss of this main supply base at Stockach compelled Kray to retreat north to [[Messkirch]], where his army enjoyed a more favorable defensive position. It also meant, however, that any retreat by Kray into Austria via Switzerland and the [[Voralberg]] was cut off.<ref>Sloane, 109</ref>

On 4 and 5 May, the French launched repeated and fruitless assaults on the Messkirch. At nearby [[Sauldorf|Krumbach]], where the Austrians also had the superiority of position and force, the 1st Demi-Brigade took the village and the heights around it, which gave them a commanding aspect over Messkirch.  Subsequently, Kray withdrew his forces  to [[Sigmaringen]], followed closely by the French. Fighting at nearby [[Battle of Biberach (1800)|Biberach an der Ris]] ensued on 9 May; action principally consisted of the 25,000  man-strong French "Center", commanded by [[Laurent de Gouvion Saint-Cyr]] against a Habsburg force of similar size.<ref>Sloane, pp. 109–110.</ref>  Again, on 10 May, the Austrians withdrew with heavy losses, this time to Ulm.<ref>Digby Smith, ''Napoleonic Wars Databook.'' London: Greenhill Press, 1998, p. 178.</ref>

==Order of battle==

===French===
[[File:Jean_Victor_Marie_Moreau_(1792).jpg|thumbnail|Jean Victor Moreau commanded the French Army of the Rhine.]]
Sources are unclear which forces were present.  Certainly, it was approximately 40,000 troops, and possibly 60,000, well above the 10,000–30,000 total Austrian and Württemberg numbers.  Contemporary accounts place the 94th Demi-brigade at the center of action in [[Gremheim]], a village between Höchstädt and Donauwörth, about {{convert|.5|mi|km}} from Blindheim.<ref>History, p. 183.</ref>  This suggests the presence of General Claude Jacques Lecourbe 's Corps, including the forces of generals [[Anne Gilbert de Laval|Laval]], [[Gabriel Jean Joseph Molitor|Molitor]], [[Henri-Antoine Jardon|Jardon]], and [[Dominique Vandamme|VanDamme]].<ref>Smith, p. 177.</ref>  This is also confirmed in an extract of Moreau's dispatch to the French Minister of War, published in the <u>London Chronicle</u>, 10 June 1800.  "The 6th chasseurs, 13th cavalry, 4th hussars and 11th chasseurs distinguished themselves in this affair.  The rest of the division, and that of LeClere, passed rapidly the Danube... General Grenier was equally well prepared."<ref>''Extract of a letter from Gen. Moreau to the Minister of War, Neresheim, June 20.''<u> The London Chronicle.</u> vol. 87., Found in Willem Lodewyk,  Van-Es, ''The Life of Napoleon Buonaparte ...: With a Concise History of the Events'' W. Day, 1810 – France, pp. 31–35.</ref>  In his ''Art of War'',  Baron [[Antoine-Henri Jomini]] also refers to General [[François Louis Dedon-Duclos|Dedon-Duclos]] as having a key role in the French success at Höchstädt.<ref>Baron [[Antoine-Henri Jomini]], ''The Art of War,'' Wilder Publications, 2008, p. 173. Originally published in English in 1862.</ref>

===Austrian===

The Allied force included approximately 20,000 Habsburg regulars and Württemberg's contingent of troops raised for the war:<ref name="Smith, 178">Smith, 178.</ref>

*FZM Count [[Anton Sztáray]], Commanding

** FML von [[Ferdinand August Freiherr von Hügel]]'s Württemberg Contingent, including
***General Beulwitz, Infantry Regiment Beulwitz, Seckendorf and Seeger (1 battalion each)
***Füss-Jägers (three companies);
***Garde du Corps (1 squadron)
***3 squadrons of Light Horse
***Contingent regiments commanded by von Zobel, von Mylius, and von Oberniz (1 battalion each)
***20 guns

**Austrian Regulars
***Royal Regiment Albert, Number 3 (6 squadrons)
***Hohenzollern Number 8 (6 squadrons)
***[[Hussar]] Regiment Vécsey Number 4 (8 squadron)
***Blankenstein Number 6 (8 squadron)

Total Austrian/Württemberg force: 20,000 men.<ref name="Smith, 178"/>

==Dispositions==
Kray assumed that Moreau would follow him to fortress at Ulm, on the Danube, where he arrayed most of the Austrian regulars and Württemberg contingent and supplies.  This position gave him ready access to both shores of the river and effectively, he assumed, blocked Moreau's path into Bavaria.  At several points east on the Danube,  he posted modest forces to protect the river crossings there, and to dismantle, if necessary, the stone bridges across the river. Several bridges crossed the river between Ulm and [[Donauwörth]], which lay downstream to the east, and each presented a strategic point at which to rupture Kray's potential line of march into Bavaria: [[Leipheim]], [[Gunzburg]], [[Gundelfingen an der Donau|Gundelfingen]],[[Lauingen]], [[Dillingen an der Donau|Dillingen]], [[Höchstädt]], [[Steinheim]], Gremheim, and [[Elchingen]].<ref name="ReferenceA">''Extract of a letter from Gen. Moreau...''</ref>

According to Moreau's narrative, he intended to force Kray to either come to battle outside Ulm, or to abandon the city.  Ulm obstructed unfettered French access into Bavaria, and blocked the main force of the Army of the Rhine.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>  To keep his forces secure, accepted military wisdom required that Moreau secure at least half of the crossings of the river, and that his troops follow a line of march perpendicular to the river.  This would prevent them from having to fight a battle (or a skirmish) with their backs to the river.  The more bridges his force could take, the more secure the approach on Ulm.<ref>Jomini, p. 173.</ref>

==General engagement==

Moreau appeared to march toward Ulm, which lay some twenty miles east of Sigmaringen and Biberach an der Ris, where his army and Kray's had engaged a few days earlier.  Instead of striking directly at the well-fortified and supplied city, however, his  force suddenly veered to the east and struck at the smaller forces posted between Ulm and Donauwörth.<ref>David Eggenberger, "Höchstädt II", ''An Encyclopedia of Battles'', Dover Publications, 2014, p. 193.</ref>  Lecourbe first secured posts in [[Landsberg am Lech|Landsberg]] and [[Augsburg]], and left sufficient rearguard troops to protect himself from [[Prince Heinrich XV of Reuss-Plauen|Prince Reuss-Plauen]], who remained in the Tyrol guarding mountain access to Vienna.  He then approached Dettingen, Blindheim (Blenheim) and Höchstädt.  The Corps of General [[Paul Grenier|Grenier]] has been posted with their right flank to the Danube and Gunzburg, and their left flank at Kinsdorf.  General [[Antoine Richepanse|Richepanse]]  protected both shores of the [[Iller]], covering the road from Ulm south to [[Memmingen]], and secured communication with Switzerland; there, he withstood considerable skirmishing with the Austrians.  Three divisions of reserve remained at the hamlets of Kamlack and Mindel, to support the attack made by General Lecourbe on Ulm, in a case it should succeed, or Grenier's attack upon Gunzburg, in case Lecourbe should not succeed.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>

Lecourbe made several feints on the bridge at Dillingheim, but his reconnaissance suggested instead that he focus on the bridges at Gremsheim, Blindheim and Höchstädt, which he did the next day.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>  A small group of 80 or so men from the 94th Demi-Brigade managed a spectacular crossing of the river.  After stripping their clothing and weapons, and loading them into a small raft, the naked men swam the river, pulling their weapons on rafts behind them.  Once reaching the other side, they took possession of several guns and some ammunition, wood, and materials.  Here they held their position until some artillery men managed to scramble across the wreck of the bridge at Gremsheim and support them.  The [[Pioneer (military)|pioneers]] and bridge builders reconstructed the bridges under Austrian fire, allowing the remainder of the 94th crossed the river.<ref>"Höchstädt", ''History of the Wars of the French Revolution: Including Sketches of the Civil History of Great Britain and France, from the Revolutionary Movements, 1788, to the Restoration of a General Peace, 1815'', Kuhl, France, 1820, p. 181.</ref>  This accomplishment seemed to mark the turning point of the action, at least it did to Moreau, who mentioned it at length in his dispatch.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> A full Austrian Corps maintained a stand at Höchstädt, but were dislodged by repeated attacks of [[carabine]]rs, [[Cuirass|curassier]]s and hussars, who took about 2,000 of the Austrians and Würtembergers as prisoners, along with some cannons and standards.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>

==Aftermath==
[[File:Leopold Kupelwieser 001.jpg|thumbnail|left|Emperor Francis II replaced Paul Kray (1735–1804) with his brother, Archduke John (above), after the Kray's losses in the Danube campaign.]]
Once the French had secured the downstream shores of the Danube, Kray had no choice but to evacuate his corps from Ulm, leaving only a small garrison behind.  The French invested the fortress at Ulm immediately, and on the 20th, the 6th Chasseurs captured a convoy of 300 wagons loaded with grain.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>  A few days later, a general armistice halted all fighting.  [[Francis II of Austria|Emperor Francis II]] dismissed Feldzeugmeister (FZM) [[Pál Kray]] and appointed his brother, the 18-year-old General-Major [[Archduke John]], to command the Austrian army. To bolster the inexperienced archduke, the emperor named FZM [[Franz von Lauer]] as deputy commander and [[Oberst]] ([[Colonel]]) [[Franz von Weyrother]] as [[Chief of Staff]].<ref>Arnold, pp. 205, 213.</ref>

The campaign culminating in Kray's evacuation of Ulm was one of Moreau's most resounding triumphs.   Napoleon Bonaparte had given Moreau specific instructions about the conduct of the campaign, all of which Moreau had ignored. Regardless, their combined efforts damaged Habsburg military operations.  In Spring 1800, while Moreau wrecked Austrian defenses in Germany, [[Massena]] and [[Desaix]] ran into stiff Austrian offensives in Northern Italy. Napoleon brought in the reserve corps and defeated the Austrians at [[Battle of Marengo|Marengo]]. The battle near Höchstädt, five days after the Austrian disaster at Marengo, allowed the French to take Munich. The combined efforts forced the Habsburgs to accept an armistice ended hostilities for the rest of the summer, but the French extracted massive levies on the Bavarians. Despite these significant losses—both of them decisive—the Austrians were reluctant to accept disadvantageous peace terms.  In mid-November, the French ended the truce and Moreau inflicted another significant and decisive defeat at [[Battle of Hohenlinden|Hohenlinden]] on 3 December 1800.<ref>Gregory Fremont Barnes. ''Napoleon Bonaparte''.  Osprey Publishing, 2012, p. 73.</ref>  The subsequent [[Peace of Lunéville]] stripped Austria of much of her Italian territories, obliged the [[Habsburg]]s to recognize the French satellites in the Low Countries, Switzerland, and northern Italy, and laid the groundwork for the mediatization of the small independent ecclesiastical and secular imperial polities by the duchies of [[Duchy of Baden|Baden]] and Württemberg, and the Electorate of Bavaria.<ref>Rothenberg, pp. 43–44.</ref>

'''Den Brook Wind Farm''' is a proposed [[windfarm]] in [[Devon]], [[England]]. The windfarm will be located {{convert|2|km}} south-east of [[North Tawton]] and {{convert|2.5|km}} south-west of [[Bow, Devon|Bow]], and will comprise nine [[wind turbine]]s, each {{convert|120|m}} high. Developer [[Renewable Energy Systems]] (RES) received [[planning consent]] for the project in December 2009,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.den-brook.co.uk/media/16981/RES%20WELCOMES%20APPROVAL%20OF%20DEN%20BROOK%20WIND%20FARM_111209final.pdf |title=RES welcomes approval of Den Brook Wind Farm |publisher=RES |date=11 December 2011}}</ref> following a long planning process which included two [[public inquiry|public inquiries]] and a [[judicial review]]. 

RES initially put forward proposals for a windfarm at Den Brook in 2004, and in response the Den Brook Valley Action Group was established to oppose the plan. A key concern was the potential impact of noise on local residents. In 2006, [[West Devon|West Devon Borough Council]] refused planning permission for the scheme, but RES appealed, and consent was granted in early 2007 following a public inquiry. Still concerned about noise issues, local residents the formed Den Brook Judicial Review Group which pursued a judicial appeal. This resulted in the inquiry decision being overturned, and a second public inquiry was held in October 2009, following which permission was once more granted, subject to a number of planning conditions. A second legal challenge was rejected in August 2010.<ref name=bbcaug2010>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-devon-11029757 |title=Den Brook wind turbine challenge rejected by High Court |publisher=BBC News |date=19 August 2010}}</ref> In 2011, the windfarm was the subject of a television documentary series, ''Windfarm Wars'', broadcast by [[BBC Two]], which followed the history of the project.<ref name=windfarmwars>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00zzwv6 |title=Windfarm Wars|publisher=BBC Television |accessdate=1 June 2011 }}</ref>

==Planning history==
RES initially publicised two alternate proposals for Den Brook in 2004: a scheme of ten {{convert|100|m|adj=on}} turbines; and a scheme of 19 {{convert|80|m|adj=on}} turbines. Following consultation, a layout of nine {{convert|120|m|adj=on}} turbines was developed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.den-brook.co.uk/about-the-project/project-layout-infrastructure.aspx |title=Project Layout and infrastructure |work=Den Brook Wind Farm |publisher=RES |accessdate=9 June 2011}}</ref> Also in 2004, RES erected an [[anemometer]] mast to measure wind speed, and undertook [[background noise]] monitoring.<ref name=storysofar>{{cite web |url=http://www.denbrookvalley.co.uk/3.html |title=The Story so Far... |publisher=Den Brook Judicial Review Group |accessdate=9 June 2011}}</ref>  

===Planning application===
By April 2005, Den Brook Valley Action Group (DBVAG) had been formed, and was flying a balloon at the site to mark the height of the proposed turbines.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/devon/4496321.stm |title=Balloon shows wind turbine height |publisher=BBC News |date=29 April 2005}}</ref> The planning application was submitted to West Devon Borough Council (WDBC) in November 2005.<ref name=application>{{cite web |url=http://www.westdevon.gov.uk/PlanningApplicationSearch/Disclaimer.aspx?PlanningID=8250%2f2005%2fOKE |title=Planning Application 8250/2005/OKE |publisher=West Devon Borough Council |accessdate=9 June 2011}}</ref> Objections to the proposal came from the [[Campaign to Protect Rural England]], [[Mid Devon|Mid Devon District Council]], and from 2,915 objection letters, all citing grounds including visual impact, noise, and residential amenity.<ref name=WDBCreport>{{cite web |url=http://www.westdevon.gov.uk/upload/public/attachments/500/oke%20apps%283%29.pdf |publisher=West Devon Borough Council |date=31 January 2006 |title=Planning & Licensing Committee: Planning Applications and Enforcement Reports (Northern Area)}}</ref> [[Dartmoor National Park]] and the [[Dartmoor Preservation Association]] also objected, as the site is located around {{convert|5.5|km}} from the national park boundary.<ref name=WDBCreport/> 71 letters of support were also received.<ref name=WDBCreport/> WDBC planning officers recommended refusal of planning permission, on the grounds of visual impacts, and potential impacts on the historic environment.<ref name=WDBCreport/> On 31 January 2006 the council voted to accept the recommendation, and refused planning permission.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/devon/4666562.stm |title=Windfarm plan refused by council  |publisher=BBC News |date=31 January 2006 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.res-group.com/media/230761/den%20brook%20decision.pdf |title=Den Brook decision: a missed opportunity to take positive action on climate change |publisher=RES |date=31 January 2006}}</ref>

Four months later, RES announced their intention to appeal to the [[Planning Inspectorate]] against the decision, and to seek a [[public inquiry]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.res-group.com/media/230757/den%20brook%20appeal%20announcement%20300506.pdf |title=RES to appeal Den Brook Wind Farm decision |date=30 May 2006 |publisher=RES}}</ref> The inquiry was held in November 2006, at which the appeal was opposed by representatives of WDBC and DBVAG. In February 2007 the appeal was allowed by the planning inspector, and planning permission granted.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/devon/6353869.stm |title=Green light for appeal wind farm   |publisher=BBC News |date=12 February 2007 }}</ref>

===Judicial review===
In March 2007, the Den Brook Judicial Review Group (DBJRG) was formed by local residents. Headed by Mike Hulme, whose property was one of the closest dwellings to the proposed site, the group came together over concerns regarding the potential for [[noise pollution]] from the turbines.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.denbrookvalley.co.uk/2.html |title=Den Brook Judicial Review Group: Who we are |publisher=Den Brook Judicial Review Group |accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref> A key concern was the potential for sleep disturbance due to a phenomenon known as amplitude modulation. This form of noise, which has been reported at a small number of windfarm sites, is poorly understood.<ref>{{cite web |author=Bowdler, Dick |title=Amplitude modulation of wind turbine noise: a review of the evidence |date=June 2008 |publisher=Industrial Wind Action Group }}</ref>

DBJRG launched an appeal, under Section 288 of the [[Town and Country Planning Act 1990]], to the [[High Court of Justice |High Court]], which was heard in March 2008 by Justice Mitting. A key issue was the refusal of RES to release the background noise data to Mr Hulme, to allow independent analysis. Although he criticised the approach taken by RES, Justice Mitting refused to overturn the result of the inquiry, since the planning inspector had not made a legal error in coming to his decision.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.denbrookvalley.co.uk/resources/High+Court+Action.pdf |title=Fresh Legal Appeal Launched Against Den Brook Wind Farm |date=March 2008 |publisher=Den Brook Judicial Review Group }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Hulme, R (on the application of) v Secretary of State for Communities & Local Government (2008) EWHC 637 (Admin) |date=19 March 2008 |url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Admin/2008/637.html}}</ref> In May, RES released the noise data, and errors were subsequently discovered by DBJRG,<ref name=furtherinformation>{{cite web |url=http://www.denbrookvalley.co.uk/resources/PressRelease_03082008.pdf |title=Den Brook Valley Wind Farm Judicial Review Information: Further Information |date=3 August 2008 |publisher=Den Brook Judicial Review Group }}</ref> although RES denied that they were significant.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.den-brook.co.uk/media/51577/den%20brook%20wind%20farm%20will%20not%20cause%20noise%20nuisance%20july%202008.pdf |title=Res reassures residents that Den Brook Wind Farm will not cause a noise nuisance |date=9 July 2008 |publisher=RES}}</ref> DBJRG then took their case to the [[Court of Appeal of England and Wales|Court of Appeal]], and permission to appeal was granted in June 2008.<ref name=storysofar/> To avoid the need for another court hearing a [[consent decree|consent order]] was agreed between DBJRG and the [[Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government]] (the defendant in the case), which had the effect of overturning the planning inquiry, and returning the matter to the Planning Inspectorate.<ref name=furtherinformation/> 

===Second public inquiry===
The second public inquiry was initially scheduled for March 2009, but was postponed at the request of DBJRG, who had not then had sufficient time to review new noise data supplied by RES.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.denbrookvalley.co.uk/resources/Press+Release+Feb+2009.pdf |title=Den Brook Wind Farm: Second Public Inquiry Postponed |date=nd. |publisher=Den Brook Judicial Review Group }}</ref> The inquiry took place between July and October 2009, with the appeal being opposed by WDBC, DBJRG, and the Campaign to Protect Rural England.<ref name=decision>{{cite web |url=http://www.denbrookvalley.co.uk/resources/Denbrook+APPEAL+DECISION-1.pdf |title=Appeal Decision: Appeal Ref: APP/Q1153/A/06/2017162, Land to the south east of North Tawton and the south west of Bow |publisher=The Planning inspectorate |date=11 December 2009}}</ref> The appeal was once again allowed in December 2009. A number of planning conditions were attached by the inspector, aimed at reducing the likelihood of noise nuisance.<ref name=decision/>

Following the decision, a second judicial appeal was launched by Mike Hulme, which challenged the validity of the planning conditions and claimed that the wording of the noise conditions rendered them ineffective.<ref name=bbcaug2010/> The case was heard by Judge Frances Patterson [[QC]] in July 2010. All ten grounds of the challenge were rejected by the judge in her decision.<ref>{{cite web |title=Hulme, R (on the application of) v Secretary of State for Communities & Local Government (2010) EWHC 2386 (Admin) |date=19 August 2010 |url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Admin/2010/2386.html}}</ref> Hulme went on to lodge an appeal against this decision, which was dismissed by the Court of Appeal in May 2011.<ref>{{cite web |title=Hulme v Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government & Anor (2011) EWCA Civ 638 |date=26 May 2011 |url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWCA/Civ/2011/638.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.denbrookvalley.co.uk/index.html |title=Court of Appeal Judgement |date=1 June 2011 |publisher=Den Brook Judicial Review Group}}</ref> Meanwhile, RES have been seeking agreement with WDBC on how the planning conditions will be met.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.den-brook.co.uk/about-the-project/site-progress.aspx |title=Site Progress |publisher=RES |accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref> 

==''Windfarm Wars''==
The [[BBC]] commissioned a documentary on the development of Den Brook Wind Farm shortly after the inception of the project.<ref name=Gibson>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/tv/2011/05/windfarm-wars.shtml |title=Windfarm Wars: Filming the renewable energy debate in Devon |date=24 May 2011 |author=Gibson, Jeremy |work=BBC TV Blog |publisher=BBC Television}}</ref> Including face-to-face interviews with a number individuals concerned with the windfarm, it focused primarily on Rachel Ruffle, project manager for RES, and Mike Hulme, local resident and member of DBJRG. Initially conceived as a single film, it developed into a series as the planning process became more and more protracted. The timescale also consumed most of the programme budget, with producer Jeremy Gibson eventally completing the films as a solo project.<ref name=Gibson/> The series was first broadcast in May and June 2011.<ref name=windfarmwars/>

*[http://www.denbrook.co.uk/ Den Brook Valley Action Group]
*[http://www.denbrookvalley.co.uk/ Den Brook Judicial Review Group]

'''Jordan Eberle''' (born May 15, 1990) is a [[Canada|Canadian]] [[junior ice hockey|junior]] [[ice hockey]] [[centre (ice hockey)|centre]] currently playing for the [[Regina Pats]] of the [[Western Hockey League]] (WHL). Selected in the first round, 22nd overall, in the [[2008 NHL Entry Draft]], he is a [[prospect (sports)|prospect]] for the [[Edmonton Oilers]].  He has won the [[Doc Seaman Trophy]] as the scholastic player of the year and is a one-time First Team All-Star in the WHL, both in [[2007–08 WHL season|2008]].  Internationally, he has competed for [[Canada national junior hockey team|Canada]] in two [[World Junior Ice Hockey Championships|World Junior Championships]], winning gold and silver in [[2009 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships|2009]] and [[2010 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships|2010]], respectively.  He was named Tournament MVP and Best Forward at the 2010 World Junior Championships and is Canada's all-time leading goal-scorer at the tournament.

==Playing career==
===Minor hockey===
Eberle played [[minor ice hockey|novice]] with Hockey Regina's tier-1 Kings and amassed 216 goals over 60 games in 1999–00.<ref>{{Citeweb|title=Eberle easily earning accolades|url=http://www.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/sports/story.html?id=63117394-e266-4fc9-8510-552ea1a78b13|accessdate=2010-01-07|date=2007-03-09|publisher=''[[Regina Leader-Post]]''}}</ref>  He went on to play [[minor ice hockey|Bantam AAA]] for the [[Athol Murray College of Notre Dame]] in [[Wilcox, Saskatchewan]], as a fourteen-year-old.<ref>{{citeweb|title='A natural to come back'|url=http://www.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/sports/story.html?id=ccab13b9-a8cb-46ff-b5e7-8940dc7dbd2b|accessdate=2010-01-07|date=2008-07-25|publisher=''[[Regina Leader-Post]]''}}</ref> After being selected by his hometown major junior team, the [[Regina Pats]] of the [[Western Hockey League]] (WHL), in the seventh round, 126th overall, of the 2005 WHL Bantam Draft,<ref>{{citeweb|title=Hockey's given Eberle more than a few Pats on the back|url=http://www.faceoff.com/story.html?id=16d56f9a-3a5c-4698-8cea-de6d1ae9586c|accessdate=2010-01-07|date=2009-12-25|publisher=[[Canwest News Service]]}}</ref><ref name=willing/> Eberle joined the midget ranks with the Calgary Buffaloes of the [[Alberta Midget Hockey League]] (AMHL).  He won a bronze medal with the Buffaloes at the 2006 Mac's Midget Hockey Tournament, scoring two goals in the bronze medal game against the Prince Albert Mintos.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Bronzed Buffs break drought|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Hockey/Junior/2006/01/02/pf-1376090.html|accessdate=2010-01-07|date=2006-01-02|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]}}</ref> He helped his team qualify for the 2006 [[Telus Cup]] national midget championship, where the Buffaloes lost a 5–4 triple overtime game in the final against the Mintos.<ref name=draft/>  Eberle scored a goal in the losing effort<ref>{{citeweb|title=Mintos magnificent|url=http://www.canada.com/saskatoonstarphoenix/news/sports/story.html?id=cff310d4-9595-46c2-b86a-c7f9cfe4e561|accessdate=2006-05-01|publisher=''[[Saskatoon Star-Phoenix]]''}}</ref> and was awarded the Most Sportsmanlike Award for the tournament.<ref name=draft/>

===Regina Pats===
Eberle debuted with the Pats in [[2006–07 WHL season|2006–07]], scoring 55 points and a team-high 28 goals in as a rookie.  He added two goals and seven points in six points against the [[Swift Current Broncos]] in the opening round of the 2007 WHL playoffs, but was sidelined for the entirety of the second round against the [[Medicine Hat Tigers]] with a virus.<ref name=key/>  Eberle started his second major junior season by earning WHL Player of the Month honours for October 2007, totaling 16 goals and 26 points over 16 games for the Pats.<ref>{{citeweb|title=October 2007: Jordan Eberle, Regina Pats|url=http://www.whl.ca/october-2007-jordan-eberle-regina-pats-p125731|accessdate=2010-01-07|publisher=[[Western Hockey League]]}}</ref>  He had missed two games early in the season with [[tonsillitis]], before scoring a [[hat trick]] in his return on October 6, 2007, against the [[Moose Jaw Warriors]].<ref>{{citeweb|title=Hats off for Pats' Eberle|url=http://www.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/sports/story.html?id=e726c68c-39e2-4254-ab93-7a7db828a8d0|accessdate=2010-01-07|date=2007-10-06|publisher=''[[Regina Leader-Post]]''}}</ref>  Eberle later represented Team WHL against Russia in the 2007 [[Subway Super Series|ADT Canada-Russia Challenge]] in late-November.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Team WHL Tops Russian Selects in 2007 ADT Canada-Russia Challenge|url=http://www.whl.ca/team-whl-tops-russian-selects-in-2007-adt-canada-russia-challenge-finale-p125837|accessdate=2010-01-07|date=2007-11-30|publisher=[[Western Hockey League]]}}</ref>   Midway through the season, he was chosen to compete in the 2008 [[CHL Top Prospects Game]] in [[Edmonton]].<ref>{{citeweb|title=14 WHL Players Named to CHL/NHL Home Hardware Top Prospects Game|url=http://www.whl.ca/14-whl-players-named-to-chlnhl-home-hardware-top-prospects-game-p125954|accessdate=2010-01-07|publisher=[[Western Hockey League]]}}</ref> 

[[Image:JordanEberlePats.JPG|thumb|220px|Jordan Eberle skates in a WHL game during the 2009-10 season.|alt=An ice hockey player in his late teens in mid-stride, carrying the puck. He is looking down towards the puck on his outstretched stick.]]

Eberle finished [[2007–08 WHL season|2007–08]] with a team-high 42 goals and 75 points.  His 42 goals accounted for one-fifth of his team's scoring and marked the first time a Pats player hit the 40-goal mark since [[Matt Hubbauer]] scored 48 in [[2001–02 WHL season|2001–02]].<ref name=key>{{citeweb|title=Eberle's offence the key to success for Pats|url=http://www.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/sports/story.html?id=432afde0-3344-4909-97e2-b09d486f8955|accessdate=2010-01-07|date=2008-03-19|publisher=''[[Regina Leader-Post]]''}}</ref>  It also tied for fourth in league scoring with [[Drayson Bowman]] of the [[Spokane Chiefs]].<ref>{{citeweb|title=2007-08 Regular Season - Goals|url=http://whl.ca/stats/statdisplay.php?type=records&subType=0&season_id=229&league_id=26&lastActive=&confId=0|accessdate=2010-01-07|publisher=[[Western Hockey League]]}}</ref>  He was selected to the WHL East First All-Star Team and received the [[Doc Seaman Trophy]] as WHL scholastic player of the year (beating out defenceman [[Jared Cowen]] of the Spokane Chiefs).<ref name=grade>{{Citeweb|title=Eberle making the grade|url=http://www2.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/features/reginapats/story.html?id=c2a80c17-a077-43c8-a760-604c430128d2|accessdate=2009-03-22|date=2008-04-30|publisher=''[[Regina Leader Post]]''}}</ref>

Eberle had started the 2007–08 season ranked seventh among WHL skaters in the [[NHL Central Scouting Bureau]]'s preliminary rankings for the [[2008 NHL Entry Draft]].<ref>{{Citeweb|title=NHL Releases Preliminary Draft Rankings|url=http://www.whl.ca/nhl-releases-preliminary-draft-rankings-p125793|accessdate=2010-01-07|publisher=[[Western Hockey League]]}}</ref>  At mid-season, he was ranked 24th among [[North America]]n skaters,<ref>{{Citeweb|title=Teubert makes a move up|url=http://www.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/sports/story.html?id=e3952346-2e62-4cdf-a1db-98eaa2de27c8|accessdate=2010-01-09|date=2008-04-25|publisher=''[[Regina Leader-Post]]''}}</ref> then dropped to 33rd in the NHL CSS's final rankings.<ref name=willing>{{citeweb|title=Eberle willing to let in the draft|url=http://www.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/sports/story.html?id=bf5abf3b-4584-4654-8421-f6e9756b434d|date=2008-06-19|accessdate=2010-01-07|publisher=''[[Regina Leader-Post]]''}}</ref>  Director of NHL Central Scouting, E. J. McGuire, described Eberle as a scorer whose strengths are his skating and stickhandling.<ref>{{Citeweb|title=Jordan Eberle|url=http://www.nhlentrydraft2008.com/featuredPlayersScoutingReport.aspx?type=nas&page=scouting&playerID=1033|accessdate=2010-01-09|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}}</ref>  He was selected in the first round, 22nd overall, by the [[Edmonton Oilers]].  Having grown up in Regina, Eberle was a childhood fan of the Oilers, the closest NHL team to the city, even after his family moved to [[Calgary]] at fourteen-years-old.<ref name=sights/>  After being selected, he commented in an interview, "If I had to pick one pick, [the Oilers] would have been it."<ref name=sights>{{citeweb|title=Team Canada champs turn sights to NHL|url=http://www.faceoff.com/hockey/nhlnews/story.html?id=22d8749b-381b-4923-8ff2-a1777d1e9aa1&add_feed_url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.faceoff.com%2Fnews.atom|accessdate=2010-01-09|date=2008-06-24|publisher=''[[Calgary Herald]]''}}</ref>

Eberle competed in his second ADT Canada-Russia Challenge for Team WHL in 2008.<ref>{{Citeweb|title=Team WHL Edges Russian Selects in Finale of ADT Canada-Russia Challenge|url=http://www.whl.ca/team-whl-edges-russian-selects-in-finale-of-2008-adt-canada-russia-challenge-p127072|accessdate=2010-01-07|publisher=[[Western Hockey League]]}}</ref>  After completing the [[2008–09 WHL season]] with a team-leading 74 points in 61 games,<ref name=entry/> Eberle was signed to a three-year, entry-level contract by the Oilers on March 23, 2009.<ref name=entry>{{citeweb|title=Oilers sign first-round pick Eberle|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/hockey/story/2009/03/23/sp-eberle.html|accessdate=2010-01-07|date=2009-03-23|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]}}</ref>  Soon thereafter, he was assigned to the Oilers' minor league affiliate, the [[Springfield Falcons]] of the [[American Hockey League]] (AHL) for the remainder of the [[2008–09 AHL season]].  He scored his first professional goal in his third game with the Falcons, a 4–3 loss to the [[Portland Pirates]] on March 29, 2009.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Eberle Scores First Pro Goal|url=http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/?id=3796914|accessdate=2010-01-09|date=2009-03-29|publisher=OurSports Central}}</ref> He went on to tally three goals and nine points in nine games.

Competing for a roster spot with the Oilers in the 2009 training camp, Eberle was one of the final cuts.<ref name=cut>{{citeweb|title=Rob Schremp, Jordan Eberle among five cut from Oilers' roster|url=http://www.chroniclejournal.com/stories_sports.php?id=214045|accessdate=2010-01-08|date=2009-09-27|publisher=''[[The Chronicle-Journal]]''}}</ref>  He was returned to the Pats on September 27, 2009,<ref name=cut/> and reeled off 25 points in 12 games to be named WHL Player of the Month for September and October.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Regina Pats' Jordan Eberle named Husky WHL Player of the Month|url=http://www.whl.ca/regina-pats-jordan-eberle-named-husky-whl-player-of-the-month-p138630|accessdate=2010-01-07|date=2009-11-03|publisher=[[Western Hockey League]]}}</ref>  He was named to Team WHL for the 2009 Subway Super Series (renamed from the ADT Canada-Russia Challenge) and was selected as an alternate captain to Pats teammate [[Colten Teubert]] for Game 5.<ref>{{Citeweb|title=Team WHL Captains and Assistants Named For 2009 Subway Super Series|url=http://www.whl.ca/team-whl-captains-and-assistants-announced-for-2009-subway®-super-series-p138893|accessdate=2010-01-07|publisher=[[Western Hockey League]]|date=2009-11-18}}</ref>

==International play==
{{MedalTableTop}}
{{MedalCountry|{{flagicon|CAN}} [[Canada national junior hockey team|Canada]]}}

{{MedalBottom}}

Eberle represented [[Alberta]] at the [[Ice hockey at the 2007 Canada Games|2007 Canada Games]] in [[Whitehorse, Yukon]].  He notched two goals and an assist in the bronze medal game against [[British Columbia]] in Alberta's 4–3 win.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Alberta wins bronze in Canada Games hockey|url=http://www.thestar.com/Sports/article/187702|accessdate=2010-01-07|date=2007-03-02|publisher=''[[Toronto Star]]''}}</ref>  Several months later, Eberle played for Team Canada's under-18 team at the [[2007 Ivan Hlinka Memorial Tournament]], but failed to register a point as Canada was kept from a medal.<ref>{{citeweb|title=2007 Memorial of Ivan Hlinka|url=http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/25540/la_id/1.htm|accessdate=2009-01-05|publisher=[[Hockey Canada]]}}</ref>  He continued with the national under-18 team the following year at the [[2008 IIHF World U18 Championships]] in [[Russia]].  He began the tournament by earning player of the game honours with a two-goal effort in the first round-robin game against [[Germany]] – a 9–2 win for Canada.<ref>{{Citeweb|title=IIHF World U18 Championships - Best Players Per Game|url=http://stats.iihf.com/Hydra/148/IHM148000_85K_10_0.pdf|accessdate=2009-01-05|publisher=[[International Ice Hockey Federation]]}}</ref><ref>{{citeweb|title=Regina Pats' Eberle Scores Twice in Canada's Win at Under-18 Tournament|url=http://www.whl.ca/regina-pats-eberle-scores-twice-in-canadas-win-at--u18-world-championships-p126233|accessdate=2010-01-07|publisher=[[Western Hockey League]]}}</ref>   He later notched two goals and an assist in an 8–0 gold medal game win to help Canada to their first tournament championship in five years.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.whl.ca/canada-defeats-russia-to-win-under-18-gold-p126271|title=Canada Defeats Russia to Win Under-18 Gold|accessdate=2010-01-07|publisher=[[Western Hockey League]]}}</ref> Eberle finished the tournament with 10 points in seven games, second in team scoring to [[Cody Hodgson]].

In his third WHL season, Eberle was selected to the [[Canada national junior hockey team|Team Canada's under-20 team]] for the [[2009 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships|2009 World Junior Championships]] in [[Ottawa]].  In the semi-finals, on January 3, 2009, Eberle was named player of the game<ref>{{Citeweb|title=IIHF World U20 Championships - Best Players Per Game|url=http://stats.iihf.com/Hydra/172/IHM172000_85K_9_0.pdf|accessdate=2009-01-05|publisher=[[International Ice Hockey Federation|IIHF]]}}</ref> after scoring two goals and the shootout-winner against Russia in a 6–5 win.  Eberle dramatically scored his second goal of the night with just 5.4 seconds left in regulation to force extra time and the eventual shootout, in which he shot first and scored.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Canada edges Russia in semis; advances to gold medal final|url=http://tsn.ca/world_jrs/story/?id=261814&lid=headline&lpos=topStory_main|accessdate=2009-01-04|date=2009-01-04|publisher=[[The Sports Network|TSN]]}}</ref>  Defeating Sweden 5–1 in the final, Eberle helped Canada to a record-tying fifth straight gold medal and was named by the coaching staff as one of the team's best three players.<ref>{{Citeweb|title=IIHF World U20 Championship - Best Three Player Per Team Selected By Coaches|url=http://stats.iihf.com/Hydra/172/IHM172000_85J_1_0.pdf|publisher=[[International Ice Hockey Federation]]|format=PDF|accessdate=2010-01-22}}</ref>  At the conclusion of the tournament, Eberle was third in tournament scoring with 13 points (6 goals, 7 assists).<ref name=IIHFU20Stats>{{cite web | title = IIHF World U20 Championships, MEN Scoring Leaders | publisher = IIHF | url=http://stats.iihf.com/Hydra/172/IHM172Z12_85B_1_0.pdf | accessdate = 2009-01-11}}</ref>

The following year, Eberle was named to his second national junior team for the [[2010 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships|2010 World Junior Championships]] in his hometown [[Regina, Saskatchewan]]. He was selected as an alternate captain to [[Patrice Cormier]].<ref>{{citeweb|title=Cormier named captain of Team Canada juniors|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/saskatchewan/story/2009/12/19/cormier-teamcanada.html|accessdate=2010-01-08|date=2009-12-19|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]}}</ref>  He was named player of the game against [[Switzerland]] in the second game of the round-robin – a 6–0 win – with a five-point game (one goal, four assists).<ref>{{Citeweb|title=Canada blanks Switzerland at World Juniors|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/hockey/story/2009/12/28/sp-canada-switzerland.html|accessdate=2010-01-08|date=2009-12-28|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]}}</ref><ref name=pog10>{{citeweb|title=Best Players Per Game|url=http://stats.iihf.com/Hydra/205/IHM205000_85K_11_0.pdf|accessdate=2010-01-08|date=2010-01-06|publisher=[[International Ice Hockey Federation]]|format=PDF}}</ref>  Two games later, he notched two goals in regulation (one of which began a two-goal comeback late in the third period) and one in the shootout against the United States in the final game of the round-robin to earn his second player of the game honour of the tournament.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Eberle carries Team Canada in times of need|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/hockey/story/2010/01/02/sp-eberle-canada-worldjuniors.html|accessdate=2010-01-08|date=2010-01-02|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]}}</ref>  Canada later met the United States again in the gold medal game.  Down 5–3 with three minutes to go in regulation, Eberle scored twice to force overtime.<ref name=topforward/>  His tying goal with 1:35 left made him Canada's all-time leading goal scorer in the tournament with 14, passing [[John Tavares (ice hockey)|John Tavares]]' mark set the previous year.<ref name=topforward>{{citeweb|title=Eberle emerges as top forward at world juniors|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/hockey/story/2010/01/06/sp-wjhc-canada-eberle.html|accessdate=2010-01-08|date=2010-01-06|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]}}</ref>  Canada eventually lost in overtime, earning silver and ending their five-year gold medal streak.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Carlson the OT hero as USA snaps Canada's gold sterak|url=http://tsn.ca/world_jrs/story/?id=304845|accessdate=2010-01-08|date=2010-01-05|publisher=[[The Sports Network]]}}</ref>

At the conclusion of the tournament, Eberle finished tied for the tournament lead in goals with [[Andre Petersson]] of Sweden and was second in points to [[Derek Stepan]] of the United States.<ref>{{Citeweb|title=Scoring Leaders|url=http://stats.iihf.com/Hydra/205/IHM205000_85B_11_0.pdf|accessdate=2010-01-08|date=2010-01-05|publisher=[[International Ice Hockey Federation]]|format=PDF}}</ref>  He was voted as the [[List of IIHF World Under 20 Championship Directorate award winners|Most Valuable Player and Top Forward]].<ref name=topforward/>  He was also named to the tournament All-Star Team by the media and named one of Canada's top three players by the coaches.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Best Players of Each Team Selected By the Coaches|url=http://stats.iihf.com/Hydra/205/IHM205000_85J_1_0.pdf|accessdate=2010-01-08|date=2010-01-05|publisher=[[International Ice Hockey Federation]]|format=PDF}}</ref>

Three days after the gold medal game, Regina mayor [[Pat Fiacco]] proclaimed January 8, 2010 as "Jordan Eberle and Colten Teubert Day" in the city for their efforts in the tournament.<ref name=eberleday>{{citeweb|title=Mayor Proclaims Jordan Eberle and Colten Teubert Day|url=http://www.reginapats.com/News/826/|accessdate=2010-01-07|date=2010-01-07|publisher=[[Regina Pats]]}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Eberle was born to Darren and Lisa Eberle in [[Regina, Saskatchewan]].<ref name=bitter/>  His dad coached him on his minor hockey teams growing up.<ref name=draft/>  He attended [[high school]] at the [[Athol Murray College of Notre Dame]] in [[Wilcox, Saskatchewan]], before moving to [[Calgary, Alberta]] at fourteen-years-old with his parents and three siblings.<ref name=bitter>{{citeweb|title=Calgary family shares Canadian juniors' bitter pill|url=http://www.calgaryherald.com/sports/Calgary+family+shares+Canadian+juniors+bitter+pill/2414992/story.html|accessdate=2010-01-07|date=2010-01-07|publisher=''[[Calgary Herald]]''}}</ref>  He returned to Regina to play junior hockey for the [[Regina Pats]] and attended [[Archbishop M.C. O'Neill High School]] during the hockey season.<ref name=grade/>  He went on to graduate from [[Bishop O'Byrne High School]] in Calgary in June 2008.<ref name=grade/>

Eberle has a cousin, [[Derek Eberle]], who also played junior for the Pats from [[1990–91 WHL season|1990]] to [[1992–93 WHL season|1993]].<ref name=draft>{{Citeweb|title=Jordan Eberle|url=http://www.nhlentrydraft2008.com/featuredPlayersDetails.aspx?type=nas&playerID=1033|accessdate=2010-01-09|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}}</ref>  His brother, [[Dustin Eberle]] was drafted by the Pats in the 12th round (248th overall) of the 2007 WHL Bantam Draft.<ref name=dustindraft>{{citeweb|title=2007 WHL Bantam Draft Round 12|url=http://www.whl.ca/draft/index.php?round=12&draft_id=4|accessdate=2010-01-10|publisher=[[Western Hockey League]]}}</ref>
